(a)  It is unlawful to let or rent any place, structure, or part thereof, trailer or other conveyance, with the knowledge that it will be used as a permanent residence or temporary residence by any person prohibited from establishing such permanent residence or temporary residence pursuant to section 62-194 of this Code, if such place, structure, or part thereof, trailer or other conveyance, is located within 2,500 feet of any school, day care center, park, or playground. 
(b)  A property owner's failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this section and shall subject the property owner to the code enforcement provisions and procedures as provided in of this Code, including action before code enforcement board and the issuance of citation by a police officer as a class III violation. In the alternative, the city may pursue any other enforcement action or legal remedy available under controlling state law, including but not limited to injunctive relief. If injunctive relief or other civil judicial relief is sought, the city shall be entitled to recover its reasonable attorneys' fees and costs from the defendant. The foregoing shall be supplemental to and not in derogation of any other remedy. 
(Ord. No. 2638-05, § 2, 7-25-05) 
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference- General powers of city, § 1.01. 
Cross reference- Department of parks and recreation, § 2-162; land development code, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2843-11, § 3.b.B., adopted June 13, 2011, repealed Art. II in its entirety. Former Art. II, §§ 66-26-66-28, pertained to parks and recreation commission and derived from the Code of 1960, §§ 30-1-30-3, Ord. No. 2055, § 6, adopted Aug. 9, 1994. 

Secs. 66-26-66-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK AND RECREATIONAL FACILITY RULES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places, § 10-3. 

Sec. 66-51. - Service or user charges. 
    Service or user charges for the use of the city's parks and recreational property, facilities or programs are authorized, provided that the service or user charges established shall be effective only upon approval by the city commission. 
(Code 1960, § 30-3.1) 
Cross reference- User and service fees and charges, § 2-189. 
State Law reference- User fees authorized, F.S. § 166.201. 
Sec. 66-52. - Park closing hours. 
(a)  The city manager may set closing hours for city parks subject to the guidelines and restrictions set forth in this section. 
(b)  In setting closing hours for each city park, the city manager shall set the closing hours based on the following guidelines: 
(1)  The amount of daylight at the time of year during which the closing hours will be in effect; 
(2)  Available artificial lighting in the park; 
(3)  The city's ability to provide and the cost of providing adequate police protection in the park during the hours in which it is open; 
(4)  The occurrence of acts of vandalism and other crimes in the park; 
(5)  Preventing deterioration of existing shrubbery and grass in the park; and 
(6)  Protecting new plantings of grass and shrubbery. 
(c)  The city manager shall not leave the following parks open during the following times: 
Park Hours Central Park 2:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. Fleet Peeples Park 2:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. Mead Gardens 2:00 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. All other parks Sunset to sunrise  
(d)  If the city manager sets closing hours other than those in subsection (c) of this section for a city park, he shall have at least one sign posted at or near a main entrance to that park stating the closing hours then in effect for that park. 
(e)  If in the determination of the city manager a particular activity can occur in a city park during the closing hours set for that park in such a manner as is consistent with the guidelines of this section, the city manager is granted authority to waive the closing hours as to that activity, so long as that activity is supervised by at least one city employee. 
(f)  No person shall use or be present on any portion of any city park during those hours that it is closed pursuant to this section, unless such person is participating in a city authorized and supervised activity provided in subsection (e) of this section. 
(Code 1960, § 30-4) 
Secs. 66-53-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARK AND RECREATION IMPACT FEE 

Sec. 66-61. - Established. 
    The city commission hereby establishes a park and recreation impact fee of $2,000.00 per housing unit for net new residential units to offset a portion of the costs associated with providing new park land for the recreational needs of the new population resultant from the net new housing in accordance with the level of service standard for park land adopted as part of the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Winter Park. 
(1)  The fee shall be assessed for net new residential housing units. Credits shall be provided for any existing housing units that were in place on the property prior to its redevelopment. 
(2)  The fee shall not be assessed for living units within nursing homes, assisted living facilities, adult congregate living facilities or other group homes, college dormitories, dwelling units on historically designated properties or for public or private funded housing meeting the definition of affordable housing. 
(Ord. No. 2559-04, § 1, 1-26-04) 
Sec. 66-62. - Park and recreation trust fund. 
    There is hereby established a park and recreation trust fund. All fees collected under the provisions of this article shall be deposited within this fund, and shall be expended only for those purposes budgeted for the acquisition of park land and recreation facilities on newly acquired park land and authorized by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2559-04, § 1, 1-26-04) 
Chapter 70 - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- General powers of city, § 1.01. 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; home solicitation sales, F.S. § 501.021 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Duly licensed permanent place of business means any regularly established store or business having a permanent address within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Peddlers, canvassers, salesmen, hawkers, itinerant merchants and vendors means all persons not having a permanent duly licensed place of business within the corporate limits of the city and who are seeking to sell, give or in any way dispose of goods, services, wares or merchandise of every kind and nature. 
    Solicitor means every person seeking or soliciting funds or services of any kind or nature and for any purpose whatsoever. 
(Code 1960, § 23-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-2. - Exemptions. 
    The following classes of persons shall be exempt from the terms and provisions of this chapter: 
(1)  Representatives of established and recognized newspapers making regular house-to-house deliveries. 
(2)  Employees of established and recognized dairies making regular house-to-house deliveries of milk and dairy products. 
(3)  All persons specifically invited by the owner or tenant to come to the house to engage in selling, soliciting, or displaying merchandise of every kind and nature. 
(Code 1960, § 23-12) 
Sec. 70-3. - Violations. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1960, § 23-23) 
Sec. 70-4. - Adoption of rules, regulations. 
    The city manager shall have the power to adopt rules and regulations for the proper conduct and operation toward the fulfillment of the purposes set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-3) 
Sec. 70-5. - Duties of police officers. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to: 
(1)  Require any person seen soliciting or peddling and who is not known by such officer to have been issued a permit to produce his identification card and permit. 
(2)  Enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-25) 
Sec. 70-6. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall engage in house-to-house and business soliciting, peddling, canvassing, selling, hawking or vending without first having fully complied with the terms, conditions and provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-14) 
Sec. 70-7. - Entering private premises. 
    It shall be unlawful and declared a nuisance and punishable as a nuisance for any peddler, solicitor, person, canvasser, salesman, hawker, itinerant merchant or vendor to: 
(1)  Enter upon a private residence in the city under false pretenses for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal services and for disposing of or peddling or hawking the goods, wares, merchandise or personal services; 
(2)  Remain in a private residence or on the premises thereof after the owner or occupant thereof shall request such itinerant merchant or transient vendor to leave; or 
(3)  Go in or upon the premises of a private residence for any such purposes when the owner or occupant thereof has displayed a "no soliciting" sign on such premises. 
(Code 1960, § 23-22) 
Sec. 70-8. - Restrictions on solicitation at private residences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor, person, canvasser, salesman, hawker, itinerant merchant or vendor to enter upon any private residence for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal services and for disposing of or peddling or hawking the goods, wares, merchandise or personal services or remain in a private residence or on the premises thereof after the hour of 6:00 p.m. or prior to the hour of 9:00 a.m. without having first been requested or invited to do so by the owners or occupants of such private residence. 
(Code 1960, §§ 18-31.1, 23-22.1) 
Sec. 70-9. - Solicitation from, in or on streets or from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit from, in or on any public roads, streets, road rights-of-way, medians or safety zones or, while located on a city sidewalk, to solicit from vehicles in the adjacent city, county or state roadways. 
(Code 1960, § 23-22.2) 
State Law reference- Peddling on state rights-of-way, F.S. § 337.406. 
Sec. 70-10. - Regulation of street performers. 
(a)  Intent. The City Commission of the City of Winter Park recognizes that street performers, as defined in this section, are afforded rights defined in established federal and Florida law relating to freedom of expression and freedom of speech. The city commission further desires to balance such rights with significant and substantial governmental interests related to the public health, safety, and welfare as outlined herein. The city commission finds that street performers in certain areas of the city defined herein and designated as the prohibited public area have interfered with and have a substantial likelihood of interfering with pedestrian and vehicular traffic of the city, including residents, business owners and occupants, and visitors and tourists by, among other things, attracting audiences which congest the prohibited public area, increase the likelihood for conflict and disorderliness, and may impede the ability of emergency response personnel to reach various locations. Moreover, such street performers may cause or contribute to pedestrian and vehicular safety risks through increased congestion, sight obstruction and obfuscation, and obstruction of pedestrian rights-of-way and crosswalks. The city finds that the existence of street performers in the prohibited public area adversely affects the city's interests in maintaining the aesthetics of the prohibited public area and character of same in a city with a unique historic downtown district. Additionally, the city finds that such street performers adversely affect the interests of residents and code compliant businesses and museums in the enjoyment of peace, repose, and quiet in their homes, businesses, and museums. Therefore, it is the intent of the city to regulate and limit street performers from performing in the prohibited public area of the city. It is the further intention of the city to balance the above-referenced regulations and governmental interests with the recognized rights of street performers to practice freedom of speech and freedom of expression to their intended audiences. Accordingly, the city further intends for street performers subject to these provisions to be afforded ample alternative channels of communication and expression and reasonable access to proximate performance areas where the street performers may reach their intended audience. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words, terms, and phrases, shall have the following meanings subscribed to them except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Perform and performance means to engage in any of the following activities: acting; singing; playing musical instruments; puppetry; pantomiming, miming; performing or demonstrating magic or acts of illusion; dancing; juggling; or the public display of and composition or creation of crafts, sculpture, artistry, writings, or compositions, including the application of brush, pastel, crayon, pencil, or other similar objects applied to paper, cardboard, canvas, cloth or to other similar medium. 
    Prohibited public area means the pedestrian accessed public areas of the central business and Hannibal Square districts along Park Avenue from Fairbanks Avenue to Swoope Avenue, and along New England Avenue from Park Avenue to Pennsylvania Avenue including the area within 50 feet of the public right-of-way of Park Avenue and New England Avenue on the public lanes, streets, thoroughfares, and ways, including the Winter Park train station and the public property at what is known as the Winter Park Farmer's Market and the Winter Park Historical Association located at 200 West New England Avenue, excluding public performance zones as provided in subsection (d)(2). A map of the prohibited public area is attached as exhibit "1". 
    Prohibited street performer activity means any activity performed, effectuated, or directed by any street performer during a performance that involves the utilization of any spray painting, or the use of aerosols or propellants, including air pressure, to spray or apply any liquid. Prohibited street performer activity also includes the utilization of fire during a performance. 
    Street performer means individuals or groups who perform in a public area or areas for the purpose of providing public entertainment or whose performance otherwise has the effect of drawing a crowd or audience. 
(c)  Prohibition. No street performers may perform in the prohibited public area, and no street performer may perform a prohibited street performer activity in the city. 
(d)  Permitted performances and conditions. Street performers may perform in the following locations and circumstances: 
(1)  Public areas not encompassed in the prohibited public area. Street performers may perform in all public areas of the city where the public is allowed, including, without limitation, the public performance zone(s) provided in subsection (d)(2) except those areas designated as the prohibited public area as set forth in subsection (b)(3) of this section. Notwithstanding the preceding, street performers shall not perform in locations or in a manner that: 
a.  Unreasonably interferes with, obstructs, or obfuscates the visibility or sight distances of any motorist traveling on or entering or exiting any street, thoroughfare, or right-of-way of the city; 
b.  Unreasonably interferes with, obstructs, or impedes the safe and orderly movement of pedestrian traffic proximate to city crosswalks; or 
c.  Is in violation of any other city ordinance. 
(2)  Public performance zone(s). Street performers may perform in the public performance zone(s), which includes the entirety of Central Park and such other public performance zone(s) as are designated by the city manager or his or her designee. The location of the public performance zone(s) shall at all times be reasonably proximate to the prohibited public area to ensure that street performers may reach their intended audiences. A map of the public performance zone(s) shall be provided upon request. Notwithstanding the preceding, the city manager or his or her designee may restrict, limit, or modify any public performance zone(s) for special events or private events where street performers would likely interfere with the event or portions thereof. To the extent such special events or private events necessitate the closing of customary public performance zone(s), the city manager or his or her designee may provide alternative or additional public performance zone(s) as identified on the attached appendix "1-4" or as may otherwise be designated as necessary. All street performers who perform in any public performance zone(s) shall not perform in a location or in a manner that is in violation of any other city ordinance. 
(e)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-7 of the City Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 3023-15 , § 2, 12-14-15) 
Editor's note- The above-referenced appendices "1-4" have been adopted by reference as though fully set out herein and are on file in the offices of the city for viewing during normal business hours. 
Secs. 70-11-70-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 70-36. - Required. 
    No person shall act as a peddler, canvasser, salesman, hawker, itinerant merchant, vendor or solicitor without a permit issued by the city. 
Sec. 70-37. - Application for identification cards and permits; fees. 
(a)  Applicants for identification cards and permits under this article must file with the city manager a sworn written application in duplicate, on forms to be furnished by the city manager, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the solicitation business and the goods to be sold. Where goods to be sold are products of farm or orchard, peddlers must state whether such goods are self-produced or grown and, if so, how many acres are in production and where the acreage is located; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the vehicle, together with the license number or other means of identification; 
(7)  The place any goods or property proposed to be sold by order for future delivery are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed and the proposed method of delivery; 
(8)  Two photographs of the applicant, taken within 60 days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be not larger than two inches by two inches and not smaller than one inch by one inch, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(9)  The name of at least two reliable references, preferably in the county, who will attest to the applicant's good character and business respectability or, in lieu of the names of references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to evaluate properly such character and business responsibility; 
(10)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; and 
(11)  A statement of a reputable physician dated not more than ten days prior to submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of contagious, infectious or communicable disease. Such a statement shall be submitted also upon the renewal of any permit under this article. 
(b)  At the time of filing the application, a fee in the amount established by the city shall be paid to the director of finance to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated in this section. 
(Code 1960, § 23-15) 
Sec. 70-38. - Credentials. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons, organizations, societies, associations and corporations applying for a permit as provided by this article to furnish proper credentials to the city. Such credentials may be in the form of a letter, card or memorandum, signed by the person or official directly in charge of such solicitation, certifying that the bearer thereof is authorized to represent the person or organization conducting the solicitation. 
(Code 1960, § 23-21) 
Sec. 70-39. - Interview and investigation of applicants for permits. 
    The city manager is empowered to interview and to investigate all persons not excepted seeking to engage in house-to-house and business canvassing, soliciting, selling, peddling or vending merchandise within the corporate limits of the city and to recommend to the city commission the issuance or rejection of permits to the persons so applying. 
(Code 1960, § 23-2) 
Sec. 70-40. - Submission of credit reports, references and fingerprints. 
    The city manager may, in order to facilitate his investigation, require from any and all persons desiring to secure permits for house-to-house and business canvassing the submission of credit reports, references, fingerprints and such other information as may facilitate the due and proper investigation of the persons so applying. 
(Code 1960, § 23-4) 
Sec. 70-41. - Prerequisites to issuance of permit. 
    The city manager shall issue a permit required in this article whenever he finds the following facts to exist: 
(1)  All of the statements made in the application are true. 
(2)  The applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity or, if the applicant is not an individual person, every member, managing officer or agent of the applicant has a good character or reputation for honesty and integrity. 
(3)  The control and supervision of the solicitation will be under responsible and reliable persons. 
(4)  The applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(5)  The solicitation will not be a fraud on the public. 
(6)  The solicitation when for a charitable cause is prompted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(7)  The cost of raising the funds will be reasonable. 
(Code 1960, § 23-16) 
Sec. 70-42. - Temporary interim permit. 
    The city manager may, if he deems it advisable and in the public interest, after preliminary investigation, issue to the applicant a temporary interim permit to engage in house-to-house and business canvassing, soliciting, selling, peddling or vending of merchandise of every kind and nature within the corporate limits of the city. The temporary interim permit shall be subject to confirmation or rejection by the city commission. 
(Code 1960, § 23-5) 
Sec. 70-43. - Occupational license. 
    Every person who may be granted a temporary interim or annual permit under the terms of this article shall, prior to engaging in house-to-house or business activities, make application for an occupational license. The occupational license shall be issued upon payment of the fees therefor, as prescribed by the pertinent ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 23-6) 
Sec. 70-44. - Rebate of occupational license fee upon rejection of temporary interim permit. 
    If the city commission shall reject any temporary interim permit issued under this article, the applicant shall receive an equitable rebate of the occupational license fee which may have been paid upon the issuance of a temporary interim permit. 
(Code 1960, § 23-7) 
Sec. 70-45. - Action by city commission upon recommendations of city manager. 
    The city manager shall submit, after his final determination, to the city commission his recommendations as to the issuance of permits required under this article to applicants, which list shall include all temporary interim permits issued. The city commission shall consider and act upon the recommendations of the city manager at the next regular meeting following receipt of the recommendatory lists, provided the applicant shall have had sufficient notice of the recommendations as provided in this article. 
(Code 1960, § 23-8) 
Sec. 70-46. - Recommendation of issuance or rejection of permit. 
    The city manager shall in every case make his recommendations as to the advisability of the issuance or rejection of a permit required in this article to the city commission within a maximum period of three weeks of receipt of the original application from the person seeking to engage in house-to-house and business activities within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 23-9) 
Sec. 70-47. - Appearance of applicant before city commission. 
    The city manager shall, at the time he makes his recommendations to the city commission, advise the applicant for a permit required in this article of his recommendations, thus affording the applicant an opportunity, if desired, to appear before and be heard by the city commission. The city manager shall place upon the agenda of the next regular meeting of the city commission all recommendations. However, if any applicant shall have received notification by the city manager of the rejection of an application for a permit to engage in house-to-house and business activities less than three days before the next regular meeting of the city commission, the applicant may request, if desired, an opportunity to be heard before the city commission at the regular meeting following the meeting immediately forthcoming. If the applicant so rejected does not make request to the city manager for a hearing before the city commission by the Monday noon immediately preceding a regular city commission meeting, the recommendation of the city manager shall be considered at the next ensuing regular city commission meeting and the decision of the commission will be final and not subject to appeal. 
(Code 1960, § 23-10) 
Sec. 70-48. - Occupational license fees. 
    Upon the issuance of a permit required in this article, other than for charitable causes, the permittee shall pay the occupational license fee in accordance with the occupational schedule set forth in this Code. The fee shall be in proportion to the time allowed by the permit to a period of one year, but the fee shall not be less than $10.00. No fee shall be required of a person selling products of the farm or orchard actually produced by the seller. 
(Code 1960, § 23-13) 
Sec. 70-49. - Disclaimer by city. 
    Each permit required in this article that is issued by the city shall have the following words clearly imprinted thereon: "The City of Winter Park does not endorse the validity, reliability, or merchantability of the product, cause or solicitation which this permit allows. Any misrepresentation or irregularity should be reported to the city director of finance." 
(Code 1960, § 23-28) 
Sec. 70-50. - Expiration of permits and identification cards. 
    Annual permits and identification cards issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on September 30 of the year in which issued. Permits and identification cards issued for shorter periods shall expire on the date specified in the permit. All permits may be renewed upon compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, §§ 23-11, 23-27) 
Sec. 70-51. - Exhibition of permit and identification card. 
    Solicitors and peddlers are required to exhibit their permit and identification cards at the request of any person. 
(Code 1960, § 23-26) 
Sec. 70-52. - Revocation of permit and identification card-Grounds. 
    Identification cards and permits issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by a board consisting of the city manager and the director of finance, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the application for permit. 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements made in the course of carrying on his business as solicitor or peddler. 
(3)  Any violation of this chapter. 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(5)  Conducting the business of soliciting or peddling in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Code 1960, § 23-17) 
Sec. 70-53. - Same-Notice of hearing. 
    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a permit or identification card required in this article shall be given in writing setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date for hearing. 
(Code 1960, § 23-18) 
Sec. 70-54. - Appeal upon denial or revocation of permit. 
    Any solicitor or peddler aggrieved by the action of the city manager in the denial of an application for permit required in this article or in the decision with reference to the revocation of the permit as provided in section 70-52 shall have the right of appeal to the city commission. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city commission, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for appeal. 
(Code 1960, § 23-19) 
Sec. 70-55. - Hearing on appeal. 
    The city commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal as provided in section 70-54, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in section 70-53 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the city council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1960, § 23-20) 
Sec. 70-56. - Record of violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the city manager all convictions for violations of this chapter, and the city manager shall maintain a record for each permit issued and record the reports of violations therein. 
(Code 1960, § 23-24) 
Chapter 74 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-131 et seq.; department of human resources, § 2-164. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INDEPENDENT PERSONNEL REVIEW BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-46 et seq. 

Sec. 74-26. - Created; qualifications of members. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 4.05 of the Charter, an independent personnel review board is created, consisting of five members. 
(b)  The five citizen members of the civil service board shall constitute the members of the independent personnel review board and shall perform the duties and functions of the independent personnel review board. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18(a); Ord. No. 2585-04, § 5, 5-24-04) 
Sec. 74-27. - Terms of office. 
    The members of the independent personnel review board shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18(b)) 
Sec. 74-28. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The independent personnel review board shall meet for the purpose of transacting such business as may properly come before it. The board shall annually select a chairman and vice-chairman from among its members. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum, and the affirmative vote of a majority of a quorum present shall be required for any action to be taken. Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  The board shall adopt rules necessary to the conduct of its affairs, in keeping with this article and subject to approval by the city commission. 
(c)  The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question or if absent or failing to vote indicating such fact and shall keep records of its hearings and other official actions, all of which shall be a public record retained by the city clerk. 
(d)  All meetings and proceedings of the board shall be open to the public, and notice of all meetings shall be posted in city hall not less than 24 hours prior to the meeting. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18(c)) 
Sec. 74-29. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any non-civil-service regular employee, excluding department heads and the city clerk and any probationary employees, whose employment with the city is terminated shall have the right, after exhausting all other available administrative procedures within the city, within five days after the receipt of notice of such dismissal or termination, to appeal such dismissal or termination to the independent personnel review board. Upon receipt of written notice of appeal by such removed non-civil-service regular employee, the board shall hold an evidentiary hearing within ten days of the appeal thereof. The appeal shall be deemed perfected when the written notice thereof is filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  After an evidentiary hearing, the board may either affirm the termination of employment or, if the board finds that there was not good and just cause for the termination, the board may reverse the termination and reinstate the employee. However, the board shall not have the prerogative and authority, in reversing the termination or dismissal, to impose other discipline on such employee. If the termination or dismissal of the employee is reversed, the board shall refer the matter back to the city manager for further discipline or proceedings in accordance with existing personnel policies. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18(d)) 
Sec. 74-30. - Appeal of board decisions. 
    Any removed non-civil-service regular employee adversely affected by any decision of the board may appeal such decision of the board by written application to the city commission for further review, and the city manager shall also have the right to appeal the decision of the board to the city commission if the board shall reinstate the employment of any employee. Review of a decision of the board by the city commission shall be by filing a notice of appeal within five days after rendition of the decision of the board. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18(e)) 
Secs. 74-31-74-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIVIL SERVICE FOR FIREFIGHTERS AND POLICE OFFICERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Civil service for firefighters and police officers, § 4.07. 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-156 et seq.; department of public safety, § 2-157; police department, § 2-158; fire department, § 2-159. 

Sec. 74-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief of the fire department means the chief of the city fire department. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police of the city police department. 
    Governmental authority or governing authority means the city commission. 
    Seniority means length of service on the police or fire department. 
(Code 1960, § 9-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-52. - Civil service board-Generally. 
(a)  Created; composition. There shall be a civil service board of the city composed of seven members. 
(b)  Appointments. Five of the members of the civil service board shall be appointed by the governing authority, and such appointees shall be persons of different vocations residing in the city who are not employed by the city. The remaining two members shall be chosen, one by the members of the police department and one by the members of the fire department, according to election procedures set out in this article. The chief of police and chief of the fire department shall be ex officio members of the board and shall have a voice in any proceedings but no vote. 
(c)  Terms. The terms of all civilian members of the board shall be three years, and each term shall commence on the third Tuesday in January. The terms of the police and fire department members shall be for one year. 
(d)  Officers; compensation. All members of the board shall, at the meeting held on the third Tuesday of January of each year or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, elect from its civilian members a chairman, a vice-chairman and a chief examiner. The chief examiner shall also serve as secretary. The board may appoint an assistant to the secretary as it may deem necessary. The board may employ an attorney and administrative assistants with the prior approval of the governing authority. The members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(e)  Meetings. The regular meetings of the board shall be held at 7:30 p.m. on the third Tuesday of each month at city hall or at such other places and times as a majority of the board may agree upon from time to time. Special meetings of the board may be called at any time by the chairman or any member of the board by giving at least 12 hours' personal notice to all members or at least 24 hours' mailed notice to all members or, for an emergency, such notice as may be deemed to be reasonable under the circumstances. Notice of special meetings may be waived by the board members. A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum at any meeting. 
(f)  Election of police and fire department members. The police and fire department members of the board shall be elected by secret ballot at an election conducted by the chief examiner of the board. The election shall be held on the first Monday of December of each year or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, and a notice of such election shall be posted in each department at least two weeks prior to the election date. Voting shall be by written secret ballot and shall be deposited in such a place and in such a manner as the chief examiner may designate. The chief examiner shall maintain possession of the ballots until the ballots shall have been tallied in the presence of either the chairman of the board or the vice-chairman and two other members of the board. Upon completion of the count, the votes given each candidate shall be noted and certified in writing signed by the chief examiner, the chairman or the vice-chairman and one other member of the board, and the certification shall be made a part of the minutes of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the board. A majority shall be necessary for election. An additional copy of the certification shall be posted on the bulletin board of each department. All vacancies shall be filled by same election procedures set forth in this subsection. Such elections shall be held within 30 days from the date the vacancy occurs. 
(g)  Vacancies. Vacancies because of resignations or otherwise in the position of civilian members shall be filled by the governing authority within 30 days. 
(h)  Removal. All members of the civil service board shall be subject to removal by either: 
(1)  Unanimous vote of the governing authority; or 
(2)  Majority vote of the governing authority, together with a majority vote of the civil service board. 
(Code 1960, § 9-2) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-46 et seq. 
Sec. 74-53. - Same-Functions. 
(a)  The civil service board is the sole authority of the city for administering and enforcing this article and the code of rules and regulations adopted, enacted and amended under this article. 
(b)  In addition to any other powers and duties granted to the board by legislative enactment or other authority, the board shall have the following specific powers and duties: 
(1)  The enactment, adoption and amendment of a code of rules and regulations which shall be referred to as the Civil Service Code, City of Winter Park. 
(2)  Enforcement of the provisions of this article and of the civil service code. 
(3)  Provide regulations for different grades of employment in the police and fire departments; provide for the method of application and the eligibility for employment in both departments and for promotions in grade; provide for examinations, both for appointments and for promotions, such examinations to be written and oral or either and to such extent as the board may, in its discretion, determine to be necessary for the proper evaluation of each applicant. All examinations shall be impartial, fair and practical and designed to test the relative qualifications and fitness of the applicant to discharge the particular duties of the position which he seeks to fill. No questions in any examination shall relate to the political or religious convictions or affiliations of the applicant. Applicants shall be marked on a scale to be set by the board, and those passing the examination shall be certified to the eligibility register. 
(4)  Investigate any and all matters which the board may deem necessary to enforce and properly administer this article and the civil service code. 
(5)  Hear appeals as provided for in this article. 
(6)  Initiation of any proceedings under this article, including the following: 
a.  Calling before the board any member of the police or fire department, including the chief of either department, for investigation or questioning; 
b.  Directing the preferment of charges against any member of the police or fire department, including the chief of either department; 
c.  Conducting the trial of any member of the police and fire departments, including the chiefs of such departments, on charges preferred against such member or chief as provided in this article. 
(7)  Prescribing rules and regulations for the conduct and direction of the members of the police and fire departments, their duties, hours of work, discipline and control. 
(8)  Granting or withholding approval to members of the police and fire departments, including the chiefs of such departments, for permission to engage in off-duty employment. 
(c)  All members of the police and fire departments, including the chiefs, shall be employed, retained, governed, directed and discharged as provided in the civil service code, unless otherwise specifically provided in the Charter. 
(d)  Whenever the governing authority shall determine that an emergency exists caused by riot, rebellion or public calamity, the mayor or, in his absence, a city commissioner may be directed by the governing authority to take charge of the police and fire departments and command the departments during the existence of the emergency only. 
(e)  The chiefs of the police and fire departments shall be in command of the police and fire departments respectively, and they shall be responsible to the civil service board for the performance of their duties; provided, however, that the proper correlation and cooperation of the functions and duties of the police and fire departments shall at all times be compatible with other branches of city government. 
(f)  The governing authority shall fix the number of members of the police department and the fire department in each particular grade and the pay for each grade, and such governing authority may increase or reduce the number of any grade or may abolish that grade, except that there shall be only one chief of police and only one chief of the fire department, and these offices may not be abolished. 
(Code 1960, § 9-3) 
Sec. 74-54. - Civil service code. 
(a)  Duties, hours of work, discipline and control of the members of the police and fire departments shall be governed and prescribed by rules and regulations to be adopted by the civil service board, and it is the avowed purpose of such rules and regulations to provide for the appointment, employment and discharge of persons in all positions of the police and fire departments based solely upon merit, efficiency, character and industry. 
(b)  This code and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this code shall have the force and effect of law on the members of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1960, § 9-4) 
Sec. 74-55. - Civil service members. 
(a)  All persons regularly employed by the city as police officers and firefighters shall be construed to come within the provisions of this article and of the civil service code, including the chief of police and the chief of the fire department. Neither this article nor the civil service code shall be construed to include any officer or person employed for temporary duty only. 
(b)  Members of the police and fire departments shall be employed, retained and advanced to higher grade on merit and fitness only, and the merit and fitness of any applicant for or employee of such departments for employment or for advancement therein shall be determined by a competitive examination and such other procedures as provided in this article. All grades for police and fire departments, eligibility for employment, examinations, appointments, promotions and leaves of absence shall be pursuant to regulations adopted by the civil service board. 
(Code 1960, § 9-5) 
Sec. 74-56. - Eligibility list. 
(a)  The civil service board shall prepare and keep open to public inspection an eligibility list of persons who have met all the requirements for employment as a police officer or a firefighter. Such persons shall be notified and take rank upon the eligibility list without preference to priority at the time of the examination. 
(b)  The term of eligibility of each list and of the names appearing thereon shall be fixed by the board at not more than six months. 
(Code 1960, § 9-6) 
Sec. 74-57. - Appointments; competitive class. 
(a)  Every vacancy in the police and fire departments not filled by transfer, reinstatement or reduction shall be filled by appointment from the eligibility register established for that position, subject to the following conditions: As a vacancy occurs, the chief of police or the chief of the fire department, whichever the case may be, shall nominate one of the applicants on the eligibility list to fill the position. Nominations shall be presented to the civil service board and shall be confirmed by the board unless the board shall, for a good cause shown, reject the nomination of the respective chief and require that another name be submitted. 
(b)  Interim appointments made by the respective chief of the police or fire department prior to a regular or specially called meeting of the civil service board may be made subject to the power of the board to reject such appointment as stated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  No appointment shall be deemed complete or final until a period of probation, not to exceed 12 months, has lapsed, and any such probationer may be discharged at any time within the period of 12 months upon the recommendation of the chief of police or the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1960, § 9-7) 
Sec. 74-58. - Seniority lists and eligibilities. 
(a)  The chief examiner shall maintain a seniority list, which list shall include every employee of the police and fire departments, respectively, on separate lists by order of seniority. Such lists shall list each grade separately. 
(b)  Where the numbers of a grade were reduced or where a grade is abolished, the members of such grades who are forced back to a lower grade shall be retained on the seniority list of the higher grade and marked lower grade preferential status and also placed on the seniority list of such lower grade to which forced, provided that when a member of the lowest grade is forced to inactive duty by either of such conditions, such member on inactive duty shall be retained on the seniority list of his grade for not exceeding one year and marked inactive. When any member is thus on inactive duty, his name shall be stricken from the seniority list if he does not enter on active duty within 14 days after notice has been given him by the chief examiner of the civil service board that a position is open. 
(c)  When any member of the police or fire department is retired in accordance with the retirement plans of the respective departments, under such circumstances that he may return to active duty, his name shall be retained on the seniority list with the appropriate notation "retired." 
(d)  When any member of the police or fire department is granted military leave by the board, his name shall be retained on the seniority list with the notation "military leave," but such leave shall not ordinarily be granted for more than one enlistment period. 
(e)  Eligibility lists for each grade shall be maintained by the chief of the police department and the chief of the fire department under the supervision of the chief examiner. A name shall not remain on the eligibility list for longer than six months without further examination. 
(f)  When any person on the eligibility list for any grade is appointed to such grade and fails, within 14 days after notice of appointment is mailed to him at the address shown on the eligibility list, to accept such appointment and/or fails to accept the duties of his appointment, his name shall be stricken from the list of eligibility, unless, upon good cause shown to the board at its next regular meeting, permission is granted by the board to retain the name on the eligibility list until the next offer of appointment or expiration of 12 months occurs. 
(g)  Any person on any eligibility list shall be removed therefrom if the person's efficiency rating is less than the acceptable minimum, as set forth in the civil service code, on any two occasions during any four successive efficiency rating periods. 
(Code 1960, § 9-8) 
Sec. 74-59. - Efficiency ratings. 
(a)  Efficiency ratings relative to the conduct and capacity of all employees in the classified service shall be made by the chief of police and the chief of the fire department or the assistant chief of police or the assistant chief of the fire department with the assistance of each employee's immediate supervisor, at least quarterly, on forms prescribed and approved by the civil service board. 
(b)  Records, reports and markings of efficiency in each department shall be open to inspection and review by the board. 
(c)  Each employee shall be entitled to be informed of his own efficiency rating and, in fact, shall review his efficiency ratings at least quarterly and evidence such review by signing a roster acknowledging that the rating was reviewed. 
(Code 1960, § 9-9) 
Sec. 74-60. - Promotions. 
(a)  Vacancies and positions above the lowest grades in the competitive class that are not filled by transfer, reinstatement or reduction shall be filled as far as practical by competitive promotional tests, but no promotion from one position to a higher one or to a position paying a higher salary in the competitive class shall be made until after the person promoted has, for at least six months, regularly occupied the next lower position in the same group or unless the applicant for promotion shall have given evidence of fitness by meritorious service. 
(b)  Examinations for promotion shall be conducted under the control and direction of the civil service board by the chief examiner or his agent as often as necessary. 
(c)  Notice of all promotional examinations shall be posted on the bulletin board of the department in which the promotion may be made for at least two weeks prior to such examination and shall indicate the grade or the rank of those thereto. Applicants for a promotional examination shall register in the office of the chief of the police department or the fire department, whichever may be applicable, at least two days before the day fixed for the examination. 
(d)  In all promotional examinations, the candidate shall be examined either in writing or by a practical test in such matters as will fairly test knowledge of the actual duties, responsibilities and requirements of the position to be filled and the applicant's fitness and qualifications to discharge such duties and meet such requirements. 
(e)  Where a physical test is included in the schedule for promotional examinations, such test may be added as a subject, and weight thereof may be fixed by the board prior to the promotional examination. The board may require all applicants to take lie detector, psychological and such other tests as it may deem necessary, and it shall make such investigations as may be necessary of each candidate so that it may be able to compile as complete a record for consideration as possible. 
(f)  Promotion in the police or fire department shall be from class to class from the lowest to the highest class in the department. Whenever any employee is promoted, his promotion shall be for an initial probationary period of 12 months, during which period, if he should fail to perform the duties in a satisfactory manner, the chief of the respective department, after giving notice to the employee, may recommend that the board return the employee to the next lower grade or the position which such employee formerly held. Before acting upon any recommendation of demotion during or at the end of a probationary period, the board shall give the employee an opportunity to make a statement if he should so desire. 
(Code 1960, § 9-10) 
Sec. 74-61. - Public safety director. 
(a)  If there is a director of public safety, he shall be in command of the police and fire departments. 
(b)  Such director shall be responsible directly to the civil service board for performance of his duties. 
(c)  The director is responsible to the civil service board for the complete execution of the board's rules and orders and directives under this article. 
Charter reference- Director of public safety, § 4.08. 
Sec. 74-62. - Command of each department. 
(a)  The chiefs of the police and fire departments shall be in command of such police and fire departments, respectively. 
(b)  The chiefs of the police and fire departments shall be responsible directly to the civil service board for performance of their duties. 
(c)  Each member of the police and fire departments shall be responsible for strict compliance with all rules and regulations, for maintaining discipline and morale, for prompt reports and obedience to orders of superiors, for performing his duty fully and properly and for the honest and efficient conduct and administration in every respect of his official position. 
(d)  The chiefs of the respective departments are responsible to the civil service board for the complete execution of the board's rules and orders and directives under this article. 
(e)  The chiefs of each department shall submit to the civil service board rules of conduct and duties of the personnel of the respective department for approval and adoption by the board. The rules of conduct and duties may be amended by the civil service board from time to time by majority vote. 
(Code 1960, § 9-11) 
Sec. 74-63. - Sick leave; leave of absence; vacations. 
    The civil service board shall, by regulation, provide for sick leave, leave of absence, vacation, and leave for training duties and studies for all the employees of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 1960, § 9-12) 
Sec. 74-64. - Discipline. 
(a)  The chief of the police department and the chief of the fire department, subject to the supervision and control of the civil service board, shall maintain discipline and for misconduct shall award appropriate punishment, which shall include but is not limited to reprimand, suspension, demotion or discharge. Any of the following shall be deemed misconduct: 
(1)  Malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance. 
(2)  Conduct unbecoming a member of a department. 
(3)  Conduct to the prejudice of good order and discipline. 
(4)  Violation of any rule or regulation of the civil service code or of the rules and regulations of each department. 
(5)  Any immoral or criminal act. 
(b)  Any disciplinary action contemplated against an employee shall not become effective until the chief of the respective department or, in such chief's absence, his duly authorized representative shall have first served upon such employee a written notice of the disciplinary action contemplated which shall contain one or more reasons or grounds therefor, together with such specifications or facts as will enable the employee to make an explanation and place him fairly upon his defense, giving such employee an opportunity to make an explanation and file it with the civil service board, together with a copy of such notice of disciplinary action and explanation, if any, made by the employee. 
(c)  The chief of police or the chief of the fire department or the board shall not suspend any employee without pay for more than 30 days for purposes of discipline nor shall any such suspended employee be required to work during such a suspension more than five days without pay. Successive suspension shall not be permitted. Any employee who has a notice of disciplinary action served upon him shall have the right to appeal to the civil service board, and whenever the disciplinary action is disapproved by the board and the reinstatement ordered, the employee involved may, as determined by the board, receive the pay he lost because of such disciplinary action. 
(d)  If the board orders the charges filed against him as provided in Section 74-69, the board may, in its discretion, suspend the accused pending a hearing and determination on the charges. 
(e)  Punishment by suspension for a period for not more than three days without pay may be made pending service of more formal disciplinary charges, if such suspension is specifically designated as such. 
(Code 1960, § 9-13) 
Sec. 74-65. - Investigation by board. 
(a)  The civil service board shall have the initiative in any proceedings and may, by a majority vote, call before it any member of the police or fire department for investigation. If it finds sufficient grounds to do so, the board may direct its secretary to prefer charges against any member of the police or fire department, in which event the charges shall be filed by the secretary, who shall act as a prosecutor. The secretary shall not vote in any subsequent proceedings regarding the investigation. 
(b)  The board shall adopt such procedures in conducting any investigation as it may deem to be expeditious and proper so long as such procedures are intended to promote justice without delay. 
(c)  Any citizen of the city or any interested person may file charges against any member of the police or fire department with the chief examiner of the board. All such charges must be signed under oath and the person shall set forth a detailed statement of facts. Upon receipt of such charges, unless the charges are directed against the chief of either department, the chief examiner shall refer the charges to the appropriate chief of the respective department for investigation and prompt report to the board. After hearing the preliminary investigation of the chief of the respective department, or if such charges are against the chief of either department, after hearing the investigation report of the chief examiner, the board may institute a further investigation and the board may order formal charges drawn and served upon the party charged. 
(d)  Any such charges, whether initiated by the board, a citizen of the city, an interested party, the chief of either department or the chief examiner, shall be deemed to be duly served upon the accused when addressed to the accused or delivered to the accused and either a written receipt acknowledging receipt of the charges signed by the accused or an affidavit under oath by the person delivering the charges stating that the charges were delivered to the accused at a certain time, at a certain place and on a certain date shall be deemed to be proper service. 
(Code 1960, § 9-14) 
Sec. 74-66. - Appeal and hearing. 
(a)  Any permanent employee of the police or fire department who shall be served with charges under this article or who may be suspended or discharged may appeal such suspension or discharge and demand a hearing on the charges filed against him by filing with the chairman or chief examiner of the civil service board a written notice of appeal within ten days of the day he was served with notice of his suspension, discharge or charges. Such appeal or request for hearing shall be deemed perfected when a notice thereof is filed in the office of the city clerk or with the chairman of the civil service board or with the chief examiner of the civil service board. The notice shall state the date and the nature of the disciplinary action appealed from. The board shall hear any such appeal or request for hearing within 30 days from the date of the receipt of the appeal or request for hearing as provided in this subsection. Written notice shall be given to all interested parties to such appeal or hearing of the time and place of the hearing of the appeal. The board, with the written concurrence of the appellant, may extend the time for the commencement of such hearing when the board shall determine that circumstances warrant such an extension. However, no such extension shall be granted unless the appellant shall concur. 
(b)  On the date set for the hearing of the appeal, the chairman of the board or such other member of the board as the board may choose shall be authorized to speak for the board and make decisions regarding points of law and evidence which may be raised by either party to the action; provided, however, that any member of the board may challenge the ruling of the chairman or such other member of the board appointed to perform these duties and, upon making such challenge, which may be either orally or in writing, the board shall vote upon the challenge and either sustain the action of the chairman or other appointed member of the board or reverse it. 
(c)  If the charges or specifications are filed against the accused by the chief of either department, the chief of the appropriate department shall present the evidence on the charges and specifications. If the charges and specifications are filed against the chief of police or the chief of the fire department, the chief examiner or such assistants as the chief examiner may request, including but not limited to an attorney at law, shall present the evidence in support of the charges and specifications. 
(d)  No material amendment of or addition to the charges and specifications will be considered by the board after the presentation of evidence has commenced. Any material amendment or addition to the charges and specifications desired to be made before the actual commencement of presentation of evidence shall be submitted to the board upon motion of the proper party and the accused or his attorney or representative shall be given the opportunity to present arguments against the inclusion of any such material, amendment or addition. After hearing all of the arguments, the board shall determine whether or not it shall permit such material amendment or addition. If such material amendment or addition is permitted by the board, upon request of the accused, sufficient time for preparation for defense shall be granted the accused. 
(e)  The order of evidence shall be as follows: 
(1)  The evidence against the accused shall be presented first. 
(2)  Thereafter the accused or his attorney or representative may cross examine. 
(3)  On conclusion of the presentation of evidence against the accused and all cross examination, the accused shall be permitted to produce such evidence in defense as he may desire. 
(4)  The chief of the respective department or the chief examiner or his duly appointed attorneys or assistants may then cross examine. 
(5)  Thereafter, either party may offer rebuttal evidence with the right of cross examination. 
(6)  On conclusion of all the evidence, the board shall hear such arguments as the parties may wish to offer. 
(7)  Upon conclusion of the arguments, the board shall, after such deliberation as it may deem necessary, render a written decision affirming, disaffirming or modifying the action appealed from. 
(f)  The rules of evidence as practiced in the circuit courts in the state, civil matters, shall apply. The board shall have the power to subpoena and require the attendance of witness and the production of pertinent documents. The chairman of the board or his appointed representatives shall have the power to administer oaths. 
(g)  All parties may be represented by counsel. A complete and accurate record of all proceedings connected with any appeal shall be taken and kept by the board. For this purpose, tape recording or similar devices may be used by the board. However, the board or the appellant may engage the services of a court reporter, in which event, the party engaging such services shall be responsible for payment of any fees connected therewith. The parties may, if they agree, split the costs of any reporter engaged. 
(h)  Any willful false swearing on the part of any witness or any persons giving evidence before the civil service board as to any material fact in the proceeding shall be deemed perjury and shall be punished in the manner prescribed by law for such offense. 
(i)  If the employee whose appeal is to be heard as set out in this section shall fail to appear for no good reason at the time fixed for hearing, the board shall hear the evidence and render judgment thereon. If the chief of the proper department or his authorized representative shall fail to appear at the time fixed for hearing and if no evidence is offered in support of the charges and specifications, the board may render its judgment by default or may hear evidence as offered by the appellant and render judgment thereon. 
(Code 1960, § 9-15) 
Sec. 74-67. - Resignations, reinstatements and transfers. 
(a)  Resignation of any employee shall be in writing and shall be filed with the chief of police or chief of the fire department who shall furnish copies of such resignation to every member of the civil service board within three days after the receipt of such resignation. Absence from duty prior to filing a written resignation shall be deemed absence without leave and any employee so absent shall be dismissed. A copy of all resignations shall be submitted at the next regular meeting of the civil service board and shall become a part of the permanent minutes of the meeting. 
(b)  Within one year, but not later, an employee who has resigned or who had been laid off as a result of a reduction in force may file a written request for reinstatement with the board, and such request shall be considered by the board at its next regular meeting. If the board approves any such request, the employee may be reinstated in the same grade or a lesser grade as he held at the time of his resignation; however, no credit shall be given for seniority purposes for the time spent out of the department. Any such employee being reinstated shall serve a probationary period not to exceed 12 months, during which time he may be dismissed with or without cause by the chief of the department with the approval of the board. 
(c)  Any former employee requesting reinstatement shall complete a current application form and may be required by the chief and the board to take all examinations; however, the board may, in its discretion, waive such examinations as it may deem appropriate in each instance. 
(Code 1960, § 9-16) 
Sec. 74-68. - Reports. 
(a)  The chief of police or chief of the fire department or his duly authorized representative shall submit to the civil service board at its regular monthly meeting a written report setting forth among other things the following: 
(1)  List of the members of each department, including their names, addresses and ranks. 
(2)  Any change in department personnel and rank in the previous month. 
(3)  Any recommendations for changes in departmental procedures and policies. 
(4)  Any request for additional equipment and facilities. 
(5)  Any morale problems or personnel problems. 
(6)  Any other matters which the chief may deem appropriate. 
(b)  Copies of these reports will be submitted to each member of the board at least one day prior to the meeting. 
(Code 1960, § 9-17) 
Sec. 74-69. - Filing of records, certificates, etc. 
    All minutes of civil service board meetings, original papers, applications, examinations, questions and papers, certificates, etc., are the property of the board and must be filed in the office of the board or such other office as the board may designate and kept on file until authorized to be destroyed by act of the board. 
(Code 1960, § 9-18) 
Sec. 74-70. - Funds. 
    All funds handled by either the police or fire department shall be subject to audit by the director of finance and, upon request, a copy of such audit shall be furnished to the civil service board. 
(Code 1960, § 9-21) 
Sec. 74-71. - Authority of commission to override board action. 
    The governing authority shall have the power to amend or overrule any finding or action of the civil service board upon a resolution adopted by the governing authority with at least four commissioners voting in favor of such resolution. 
(Code 1960, § 9-22) 
Secs. 74-72-74-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN 

Sec. 74-91. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Winter Park Employees' Deferred Compensation Plan, to be known and identified as such for all purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 19-20) 
Sec. 74-92. - Administration. 
    The administrator of the deferred compensation plan shall be the city manager, who shall have the rights, duties and powers provided for in F.S. §§ 112.215(5) and 112.215(6)(b), together with those additional rights, duties and powers as may from time to time be delegated by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1960, § 19-21) 
Sec. 74-93. - Authority of commission. 
    The city commission shall be empowered by resolution to provide for employee eligibility and participation, plan administration, recordkeeping and reporting, information and claims procedures, plan amendments, approval and execution of plan agreements and documents and designation of the fiduciary administrator for the deferred compensation plan. Upon final adoption, such resolution shall immediately become effective and shall be kept available for inspection by any city employee upon request. 
(Code 1960, § 19-22) 
Secs. 74-94-74-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RETIREMENT AND PENSION PLANS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 74-116-74-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 74-126. - Ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect ordinances establishing or modifying the Pension Plan for Employees of the City of Winter Park, Florida, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Secs. 74-127-74-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIREFIGHTERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2787-09, § 1, adopted Nov. 23, 2009, amended div. 3 in its entirety as set out herein. The former div. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1992, § 1, adopted Sept. 8, 1992; Ord. No. 2089, § 2, adpopted Apr. 11, 1995; Ord. No. 2113, § 2, adopted Sept. 26, 1995; Ord. No. 2205, § 2, adopted Aug. 12, 1997; Ord. No. 2224, § 1, adopted Oct. 28, 1997; Ord No. 2233, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 27, 1998; Ord. No. 2321, §§ 1-14, adopted Oct. 12, 1999; Ord. No. 2445-01, § 1, Oct. 23, 2001; Ord. No. 2477-02, § 1, adopted Aug. 27, 2002; Ord. No. 2517-03, § 1, adopted May 13, 2003; Ord. No. 2541-03, § 1, adopted Oct. 13, 2003; Ord. No. 2614-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 10, 2005; Ord. No. 2670-06, § 1, adopted May 8, 2006; Ord. No. 2714-07, § 1, adopted June 11, 2007; Ord. No. 2739-08, adopted Apr. 28, 2008. 
State Law reference- Firefighters' pensions, F.S. ch. 175. 

Sec. 74-151. - Definitions. 
1.  As used herein, unless otherwise defined or required by the context, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning indicated: 
    Accumulated Contributions means a Member's own contributions with interest, at the rate of five percent (5%) per annum through March 1, 2013. Effective on and after March 1, 2013, accumulated contributions means a Member's own contributions to the System, without interest. For those Members who purchase Credited Service with interest or at no cost to the System, any payment representing the amount attributable to Member contributions based on the applicable Member contribution rate, and any payment representing interest and any required actuarially calculated payments for the purchase of such Credited Service, shall be included in Accumulated Contributions. 
    Actuarial Equivalent means a benefit or amount of equal value, based upon the RP-2000 Combined Table based upon a fixed blend of fifty percent (50%) male mortality rates-fifty percent (50%) female mortality rates, with full generational mortality improvements projected to each future payment date for healthy participants and the RP-2000 Disabled Mortality Table based upon a fixed blend of fifty percent (50%) male mortality rates-fifty percent (50%) female mortality rates, with full generational mortality improvements projected to each future payment date for impaired participants, and an interest rate of seven and three-quarters percent (7.75%) per annum. This definition may only be amended by the City pursuant to the recommendation of the Board using assumptions adopted by the Board with the advice of the plan's actuary, such that actuarial assumptions are not subject to City discretion. 
    Average Final Compensation means one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the average Salary of the five (5) best years of the last ten (10) years of Credited Service prior to Retirement, termination, or death, or the career average salary as a full-time Firefighter, whichever is greater. A year shall be twelve (12) consecutive months. 
    Beneficiary means the person or persons entitled to receive benefits hereunder at the death of a Member who has or have been designated in writing by the Member and filed with the Board. If no such designation is in effect, or if no person so designated is living, at the time of death of the Member, the Beneficiary shall be the estate of the Member. 
    Board means the Board of Trustees, which shall administer and manage the System herein provided and serve as trustees of the Fund. 
    City means City of Winter Park, Florida. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended from time to time. 
    Credited Service means the total number of years and fractional parts of years of service as a Firefighter with Member contributions, when required, omitting intervening years or fractional parts of years when such Member was not employed by the City as a Firefighter. A Member may voluntarily leave his Accumulated Contributions in the Fund for a period of five (5) years after leaving the employ of the Fire Department pending the possibility of being reemployed as a Firefighter, without losing credit for the time that he was a Member of the System. If a vested Member leaves the employ of the Fire Department, his Accumulated Contributions will be returned only upon his written request. If a Member who is not vested is not reemployed as a Firefighter with the Fire Department within five (5) years, his Accumulated Contributions, if one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or less, shall be returned. If a Member who is not vested is not reemployed within five (5) years, his Accumulated Contributions, if more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), will be returned only upon the written request of the Member and upon completion of a written election to receive a cash lump sum or to rollover the lump sum amount on forms designated by the Board shall be returned. Upon return of a Member's Accumulated Contributions, all of his rights and benefits under the System are forfeited and terminated. Upon any reemployment, a Firefighter shall not receive credit for the years and fractional parts of years of service for which he has withdrawn his Accumulated Contributions from the Fund, unless the Firefighter repays into the Fund the contributions he has withdrawn, with interest, as determined by the Board, within ninety (90) days after his reemployment. 
The years or fractional parts of a year that a Member performs "Qualified Military Service" consisting of voluntary or involuntary "service in the uniformed services" as defined in the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA) (P.L.103-353), after separation from employment as a Firefighter with the City to perform training or service, shall be added to his years of Credited Service for all purposes, including vesting, provided that: 
A.  The member is entitled to reemployment under the provisions of USERRA. 
B.  The Member returns to his employment as a Firefighter within one (1) year from the earlier of the date of his military discharge or his release from active service, unless otherwise required by USERRA. 
C.  The maximum credit for military service pursuant to this paragraph shall be five (5) years. 
D.  This paragraph is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA. To the extent that this paragraph does not meet the minimum standards of USERRA, as it may be amended from time to time, the minimum standards shall apply. 
In the event a Member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while performing USERRA Qualified Military Service, the beneficiaries of the Member are entitled to any benefits (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service) as if the Member had resumed employment and then died while employed. 
Beginning January 1, 2009, to the extent required by Section 414(u)(12) of the Code, an individual receiving differential wage payments (as defined under Section 3401(h)(2) of the Code) from an employer shall be treated as employed by that employer, and the differential wage payment shall be treated as compensation for purposes of applying the limits on annual additions under Section 415(c) of the Code. This provision shall be applied to all similarly situated individuals in a reasonably equivalent manner.
