(Code 1960, § 15-13; Ord. No. 2709-07, §§ 1-5, 3-12-07; Ord. No. 3003-15 , § 9, 7-27-15) 
Cross reference- User and service fees and charges, § 2-189.

ARTICLE III. - UTILITY SERVICE AND FUEL OIL TAXES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 102. 
State Law reference- Public service (utility) tax, F.S. § 166.231 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 94-66-94-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - UTILITY SERVICE 

Sec. 94-76. - Levy of tax; when payable. 
(a)  There is imposed and levied by the city a tax upon each and every purchase of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum or manufactured) and water service within the corporate limits of the city in the amount of ten percent of each payment received by the seller for such utility service or commodity. Such tax shall be paid by the purchaser to the seller, for the use of the city, at the time of paying the charge therefor, but not less often than monthly. 
(b)  There is imposed and levied by the city a tax upon each and every purchase of telecommunications service which originates and terminates in this state at a rate of seven percent of the total amount charged for any telecommunications service provided within the city or, if the location of the telecommunications service provided cannot be determined as part of the billing process, the total amount billed for such telecommunications service to a telephone or telephone number, a telecommunications number or device, a service address, or a customer's billing address located within the city, excluding public telephone charges collected onsite, charges for any foreign exchange service or any private line service except when such services are used or sold as a substitute for any telephone company switched service or dedicated facility by which a telephone company provides a communication path, access charges and any customer access line charges paid to a local telephone company. However, telecommunications service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(5)(b) shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges excluding variable usage charges. 
(c)  As used in this division, terms shall have the meaning and definition given to them under F.S. § 203.012, including the terms "access charge" or "right of access," "local telephone service," "private communications service," "telecommunications service," "teletypewriter or computer exchange service" and "toll telephone service." 
(Code 1960, § 26-1; Ord. No. 2231, § 1, 12-9-97) 
Sec. 94-77. - Duty of seller to collect tax; failure of purchaser to pay bill. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum or manufactured), and water service within the city to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax levied under this division at the time of collecting the selling price thereof and to report and pay over, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, unto the city, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every seller of telecommunications service within the city to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax levied under this division at the time of collecting the selling price thereof. Every seller of telecommunications service shall file a return with the city each month, which return shall identify the name and address of the seller, the period of the return, the amount collected from the sale of telecommunications services, any collection allowance taken, the amount of tax remitted with the return, and the name and telephone number of a person authorized by the seller to respond to inquiries from the city concerning the seller's administration of the tax. The seller shall report and pay over unto the city all such taxes levied and collected on the date returns and payments of tax are required under F.S. ch. 212. The city may grant an extension of the due date for a return or payment upon written request from the seller. In the event the total amount of tax anticipated to be collected by seller of telecommunications service within a calendar quarter does not exceed $120.00, the seller of such telecommunications service may, with the written authorization of the city, remit the taxes collected during such calendar quarter to the city quarterly. In such case, the tax shall be due on or before the 20th day of the month following the end of the calendar quarter in which the taxes were collected. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect for any such service without, at the same time, collecting the tax levied, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the tax from the purchaser. Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting for any such service, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax; provided, however, that the seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected bills. If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay for any such service, including the tax imposed, the seller shall have the right and is authorized and empowered to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the bill is paid in full. 
(d)  For the purpose of compensating the seller of telecommunications service, the seller shall be allowed one percent of the amount of the tax collected and due to the city upon a timely filed return in the form of a deduction from the amount collected for remittance. The deduction shall be allowed as compensation for the keeping of records and for the collection of and the remitting of the tax on a timely basis. The deduction shall not be allowed in the event of an untimely return, unless the seller has in writing requested and been granted an extension of time for filing its return. Extensions of time shall be granted if reasonable cause is shown, whether requested before or after the due date of the return. 
(Code 1960, § 26-2; Ord. No. 2029, § 1, 1-25-94; Ord. No. 2231, § 2, 12-9-97) 
Sec. 94-78. - Records kept by seller; auditing; interest and penalties. 
(a)  Each and every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum or manufactured), water service and telecommunications service shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city of such commodities or service, which records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date thereof and the date of payment and the seller shall retain all records kept in the ordinary course of business which establish the collection and remittance of taxes due. Each seller shall preserve the records relating to such taxes until the expiration of the time within which the city may make any assessment with respect to that tax. 
(b)  Pursuant to F.S. § 166.234, upon 60 days' written notice to audit transmitted to the seller by certified mail, return receipt requested, each such seller must provide the city access to such records which shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during the seller's normal business hours at the official location of the seller's books and records. Duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make any transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. Upon reasonable request, the city must grant an extension of the due date by which the records must be made available for inspection. If either the city or the seller requires an additional extension, it must give notice to the other no less than 30 days before the existing extension expires, except in cases of bona fide emergency or waiver of the notice requirement by the other party. Any information received by the city or its agent in connection with such audit is confidential and exempt from the provisions of F.S. § 119.07(1). 
(c)  If the seller received timely notice requesting access to such records and the seller failed or refused to allow such access and did not propose an alternative date on which the audit was to commence, or if the seller and the city agreed in writing to an alternative date on which the audit was to commence but the seller then failed or refused to permit reasonable access to its books and records on the alternative date, the seller shall reimburse the city the reasonable travel expenses incurred by or charged to the city in connection with performing the audit. 
(d)  Interest shall be assessed at the rate of one percent per month of the delinquent tax from the date the tax was due until paid. In the event of willful neglect, or willful negligence, a penalty shall be assessed at the rate of five percent per month of the delinquent tax, not to exceed a total penalty of 25 percent. In no event will the penalty for failure to file a return be less than $15.00. In the case of a fraudulent return or a willful intent to evade payment of the tax, the seller making such fraudulent return or willfully attempting to evade payment of the tax, shall be liable for a specific penalty of 100 percent of the tax. Interest and penalties shall be computed on the net tax due after application of any overpayments. A seller's liability for any tax, interest or penalty may be settled or compromised by the city pursuant to F.S. § 166.234(14), upon the grounds of doubt as to liability or doubt as to the collectibility of such tax, interest, or penalty. 
(e)  The city shall prepare and furnish to the seller a report of each audit which identifies the nature of any deficiency or overpayment, the amount thereof, and the manner in which the amount was computed. Upon a finding of deficiency or overpayment, the city shall issue a determination which states the amounts of tax, interest, and penalty which the city determines is owed or due the seller together with a written narrative explanation of the basis for the city's determinations. The determination shall also inform the seller of the remedies available to it if the seller disagrees with any such determination, list the name of the person authorized by the city to approve compromises and execute closing agreements settling a dispute, and state the consequences of the seller's failure to comply with any demand of the city which is stated in the determination. A seller may file with the city a written protest of any determination within 60 days after the determination is issued. The city shall consider the protest and issue a written notice of its decision to the seller within 60 days which addresses each issue raised in the protest. The seller may petition the city for reconsideration of a notice of decision within 30 days after the issuance of the notice, and the city shall issue a written notice of reconsideration to the seller within 30 days which addresses each issue raised in the petition. 
(f)  A determination becomes final 60 days after the date of issuance, unless the seller, before the 60-day period expires, has filed a protest or secured a written extension of time within which to file a protest. If the seller has secured a written extension of time and fails to file a protest within the extended time period, the proposed assessment becomes a final assessment at the expiration of the extended filing period. If a protest is timely filed and the seller and the city are unable to resolve the disputed issues, the determination becomes final as of the date of issuance of the notice of decision, unless the seller timely files a petition for reconsideration. If a petition for reconsideration is timely filed, the determination becomes final upon issuance of a notice of reconsideration. 
(g)  The city may issue a proposed assessment of tax levied under section 94-76 within three years after the date the tax was due. However, this limitation is tolled for one year if within the three-year period the city issues to the seller a notice of intent to audit. If the audit cannot be completed prior to the expiration of this limitation period as extended by tolling, and such condition is due to the seller's refusal or delay in allowing access to applicable records, the city may make a proposed assessment from an estimate based upon the best information available for the taxable period, unless the seller agrees in writing to extend the limitations period. The city may also make a proposed assessment from such an estimate if, notwithstanding agreed extensions of the limitations period to a date which is three years following issuance of the notice of intent to audit, the seller does not allow access to applicable records prior to such date. 
(h)  A seller may apply to the city for refund for, or may take a credit for, any overpayment of tax or interest or penalty thereon within three years following remittance by the seller, and the city must refund or allow the seller credit for such overpayments as were remitted to the city. However, in the case of an overpayment which the seller has previously refunded or credited to a purchaser, the limitation period for the seller's refund application or credit shall expire three years following the seller's remittance to the city or 60 days following the seller's issuance of the refund or credit to the purchaser, whichever is later. 
(i)  Upon expiration of the periods set forth in this provision, the city's right to assess tax, interest, or penalty and the seller's right to apply for a refund or credit expire and are barred, unless fraud has occurred; however, sellers and the city may enter into agreements to extend these periods. 
(Code 1960, § 26-3; Ord. No. 2231, § 3, 12-9-97) 
Sec. 94-79. - Exemptions from payment of tax. 
(a)  Purchases by the federal government, this state, and all counties, school districts, and municipalities of the state, and by public bodies exempted by law or court order, and by any recognized church in this state for use exclusively for church purposes, are exempt from the tax authorized, imposed and levied in this division. Purchases made by any religious institution that possesses a consumer certificate of exemption issued under F.S. ch. 212, shall be exempt from the tax authorized, imposed and levied by subsection 94-76(b) on telecommunications services. 
(b)  Purchases of local telephone service or other telecommunications service for use in the conduct of a telecommunications service for hire or otherwise for resale are exempt from the tax imposed and levied in this division. 
(c)  A purchaser who claims an exemption under this section shall certify to the seller that he or she qualifies for the exemption, which certification may encompass all purchases after a specified date or other multiple purchases. For purchases made under subsection 94-79(b) which are exempted, upon the presentation of a certificate, from the tax imposed by F.S. ch. 212, the certification required by this subsection may be satisfied by presentation of a certification that satisfies the requirements of F.S. ch. 212. A seller accepting the certification required by this subsection is relieved of the obligation to collect and remit tax; however, a governmental body that is exempt from the tax authorized by this division shall not be required to furnish such certification, and a seller is not required to collect tax from such an exempt governmental body. Governmental bodies which sell or resell taxable service to non-exempt end users must collect and remit the tax authorized, imposed and levied under this division. 
(Code 1960, § 26-4; Ord. No. 2231, § 4, 12-9-97) 
Sec. 94-80. - Interest penalty for late payment. 
    Any seller of telecommunications service failing to remit to the city on or before the 15th day of each calendar month all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding month shall be liable for interest on the unpaid amount at the rate of one percent per month, not to exceed 12 percent per annum. This interest shall accrue from the due date until the date such taxes are received by the city. Any taxes found to be due to the city from the seller as a result of any audit or examination of such records shall bear interest at the above stated rate from the time such taxes were due until such time as they are received by the city; provided, however, that the city may settle or compromise any dispute over interest due pursuant to this section as it is reasonable under the circumstances. As used herein, the due date shall mean the 15th day of the month following the month in which such taxes were collected. 
(Ord. No. 2029, § 2, 1-25-94) 
Secs. 94-81-94-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FUEL OIL 

Sec. 94-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fuel oil includes fuel oil grades no. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6; kerosene; and coal oil. 
(Code 1960, § 26-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-92. - Levy of tax; amount. 
    There is imposed and levied by the city on each and every purchase of fuel oil in the corporate limits of the city a tax in the amount of ten percent of the payments received by the seller of such fuel from the purchaser thereof, but not more than $0.04 per gallon. The tax in every case shall be collected from the purchaser of such fuel oil and paid by such purchaser for the use of the city to the seller thereof at the time of the purchaser paying the charge therefor to the seller, but not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1960, § 26-13) 
Sec. 94-93. - Exclusion. 
    The following are excluded from the tax levied and imposed under this division: 
(1)  Purchases of special fuels as defined in F.S. ch. 209. 
(2)  The purchase of not more than five gallons of fuel oil delivered at the seller's place of business into the purchaser's container of not more than five-gallon capacity. 
(3)  The purchase of fuel oil for use in the propulsion of ships, motor vessels, motorboats, aircraft, railroad trains and other modes of transportation. 
(Code 1960, § 26-15) 
Sec. 94-94. - Duty of seller to collect tax; failure of purchaser to pay bill. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller of fuel oil, in acting as the tax collecting medium or agency for the city, to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax levied and imposed by this division at the time of collecting the purchase price charged for such sale and to report and pay over, on or before the 15th day of each calendar month, to the city all such taxes imposed and levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. It shall be unlawful for any seller of fuel oil to collect the price of any sale of fuel oil without at the same time collecting the tax imposed and levied in respect of each purchase thereof, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the tax from the purchaser. Any seller of fuel oil failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of such sale, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the tax had been actually paid by purchaser thereof to the seller. The city manager shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and shall take such proceedings in the name of the city as shall be necessary for the collection or recovery of such tax; provided, however, that the seller of such fuel oil shall not be liable for payment of such tax upon uncollected charges. If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge for such sale and the tax imposed and levied and as required on account of the purchase for which such charge is made or either, the seller is vested with the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1960, § 26-16) 
Sec. 94-95. - Records kept by seller. 
    Each and every seller of fuel oil shall keep complete records showing all purchases within the corporate limits of the city of fuel oil, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the period of time covered thereby, the amount of tax levied and imposed under this division and the date of payment thereof. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized officers or agents of the city during business hours on all business days, and the duly authorized officers or agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts therefrom during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1960, § 26-17) 
Sec. 94-96. - Exemptions. 
    The United States, the state, the county, the city, their commissions and agencies, and public educational institutions and other tax-supported bodies, authorities, boards and commissions are exempted from the payment of the taxes imposed and levied under this division. 
(Code 1960, § 26-18) 
Sec. 94-97. - Computation of tax. 
    In all cases where the seller of fuel oil collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax imposed and levied in this division may be computed on the aggregate amount of purchases during such monthly period, provided the amount of the tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1960, § 26-19) 
Sec. 94-98. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any purchaser willfully failing or refusing to pay the tax imposed and levied in this division, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, and any seller willfully violating the provisions of this division or any officer, agent or employee of any such seller willfully violating the provisions of this division shall upon conviction thereof be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1960, § 26-20) 
Secs. 94-99-94-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION FOR SENIOR CITIZENS 

Sec. 94-126. - Authority. 
    This article is enacted in compliance with and pursuant to F.S. chs. 166 and 196, and Section 6(f), Article VII of the Constitution of the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 1, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-127. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. Words not defined herein shall have those meanings ascribed in F.S. § 196.075, as the same may be amended from time to time. When not inconsistent with the context, words are to be gender neutral, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City means the City of Winter Park, Florida, a municipal corporation organized and existing under the laws of the State of Florida. 
    City limits means the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 2, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-128. - Additional homestead exemption. 
    There is hereby granted an additional homestead exemption of $50,000 for any person who has legal or equitable title to real estate in the city limits and maintains thereon the permanent residence of the owner, who has attained age 65, and whose household income does not exceed $20,000.00. If title is held jointly with right of survivorship, the person residing on the property and otherwise qualifying may receive the entire amount of the additional homestead exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 3, 11-27-01; Ord. No. 2712-07, § 2, 5-29-07) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 2712-07, adopted May 29, 2007, stated the following: "Once enacted, a copy of this ordinance shall be delivered to the Orange County Property Appraiser no later than June 1, 2007, allowing the exemption to begin. In the event this ordinance is ever repealed, the City shall notify the Orange County Property Appraiser no later than December 1 of the year prior to the year the exemption expires." 
Sec. 94-129. - Adjustment to household income limitation. 
    Beginning January 1, 2001, and for as long as permitted by Florida Statute, the $20,000.00 household income limitation shall be adjusted annually, on January 1, by the percentage change in the average cost-of-living index in the immediate prior calendar year compared with the calendar year prior to that. The index is the average of the monthly consumer-price-index figures for the stated 12-month period, relative to the United States as a whole, issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 4, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-130. - Exemption applies only to city taxes. 
    The additional homestead exemption granted pursuant to section 94-129 above shall apply only to ad valorem taxes levied by the city at the millage rate adopted by the city for the respective year. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 5, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-131. - Applicability to dependent special districts and MSTU's. 
    The additional homestead exemption granted pursuant to Section 94-129 above shall not apply to ad valorem tax levies of any dependent special district or municipal service taxing unit within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 6, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-132. - Sworn statement of household income. 
    To be entitled to the additional homestead exemption, a taxpayer claiming the exemption must annually submit to the county property appraiser, not later than March 1, a sworn statement of household income on a form prescribed or approved by the department of revenue. The Florida Department of Revenue may require that the statement be supported by copies of any federal income tax returns for the prior year, any wage and earnings statements (W-2 forms), and any other documents the property appraiser finds necessary, for each member of the household, to be submitted by June 1, and that the taxpayer's statement attest to the accuracy of such copies. If the Florida Department of Revenue imposes such a requirement, then the county property appraiser shall not allow the exemption without such supporting documentation. Failure to submit the sworn statement by March 1 or the other required documentation by June 1 of a given year shall constitute a waiver of the additional homestead exemption for that year. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 7, 11-27-01) 
Sec. 94-133. - Other statutory conditions. 
    Receipt of the additional homestead exemption provided for herein shall also be subject to the provisions of F.S. § 196.131, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2448-01, § 8, 11-27-01) 
Chapter 98 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- General powers of city, § 1.01. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 90; vehicles for hire, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; traffic generally, F.S. ch. 316; powers of local authorities, F.S. §§ 316.002, 316.007, 316.008. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the Winter Park Traffic Code. 
(Code 1960, § 28-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except when the context otherwise requires. Whenever any words and phrases used in this chapter are not defined in this section but are defined in the state laws regulating the operation of vehicles, any such definition in state law shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used in this chapter, except when the context otherwise requires. 
    Commercial vehicle means every vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of property and which displays lettering thereon advertising the owner of the vehicle. 
    Freight curb loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb for the exclusive use of commercial vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight. 
    Parkway means that portion of a street not designated or intended for the use of pedestrians and located between the curb and the adjacent property lines or between the edge of pavement and the adjacent property lines where there is no curb or between the established vehicular traveled way and the adjacent property lines on unpaved streets. 
    Passenger curb loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Traffic division means the traffic division of the police department or, if a traffic division is not established, the term shall be deemed to refer to the police department. 
(Code 1960, § 28-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 316.003. 
Sec. 98-3. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer exclusively to the operation of vehicles upon highways and city offstreet parking lots, except where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. 
(Code 1960, § 28-2) 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction of municipal traffic ordinances, F.S. § 316.006(2). 
Sec. 98-4. - Duties of person propelling pushcart. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter and by the rules of the road portion of the state vehicle code, except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1960, § 28-21) 
Sec. 98-5. - Skateboarding. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central business district means that area of the city lying within and bounded by Interlachen Avenue on the east, Fairbanks Avenue on the south, New York Avenue on the west and Swoope Avenue on the north. 
    Skateboard means a board made of wood, fiberglass, plastic, metal or other material or combination of materials mounted on two or more axles, front and rear, with two or more wheels made of clay, polyurethane, rubber or other material or combination of materials attached to each axle. The word "skateboard" includes motorized skateboards propelled by a motor mounted on the skateboard. 
    Skateboarding means lying, sitting, squatting, kneeling or standing upon a skateboard and propelling oneself by any means which causes the skateboard to move, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Jumping on a skateboard; 
(2)  Being pulled or pushed while situated on a skateboard; 
(3)  Pushing the ground or other surface with one foot while keeping one's other foot on the skateboard; 
(4)  Riding a skateboard from one elevation to a lower elevation; or 
(5)  Operating a motor mounted on a skateboard. 
(b)  Prohibitions. Skateboarding is prohibited on all streets, sidewalks, alleys and parks within the central business district. 
(Code 1960, § 28-91) 
Sec. 98-6. - Bicycle riding. 
(a)  Official bike paths shall be used in lieu of city streets where available and so long as their use will not endanger the safety of pedestrians. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk within the central business district of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 6-4(b), (c)) 
State Law reference- Bicycle regulations, F.S. § 316.2065; authority to regulate bicycle operation, F.S. § 316.008(1)(h). 
Sec. 98-7. - Bicycles obstructing streets or sidewalks. 
    No bicycle shall be left upon any street or sidewalk in such a manner as to obstruct traffic, either of vehicles or pedestrians, or to obstruct any stopping or parking space. 
(Code 1960, § 6-6) 
State Law reference- Bicycle regulations, F.S. § 316.2065; authority to regulate bicycle operation, F.S. § 316.008(1)(h). 
Secs. 98-8-98-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-31. - Authority of police and fire department officials. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to enforce all street traffic laws and regulations of this city and all of the state vehicle laws. 
(b)  Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws. If a fire or other emergency occurs or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(c)  Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic at the scene or in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1960, § 28-20) 
State Law reference- Authority to direct traffic by means of police officers, F.S. § 316.008(1)(b); obedience to police and fire department officials, F.S. § 316.072(3). 
Sec. 98-32. - City traffic engineer. 
(a)  Office established. The office of city traffic engineer is established. The city engineer shall serve as city traffic engineer in addition to his other functions and shall exercise the powers and duties with respect to traffic as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the general duty of the city traffic engineer to: 
(1)  Determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices; 
(2)  Conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents and devise remedial measures; 
(3)  Conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions; 
(4)  Plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of this city and cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions; and 
(5)  Carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1960, § 28-15) 
Sec. 98-33. - Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The chief of police, by and with the approval of the city manager, is empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than 90 days, unless before the expiration of 90 days the required steps have been taken to make the regulation permanent. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 28-16) 
Sec. 98-34. - Impounding vehicles. 
(a)  Members of the police department may remove a vehicle from a street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety or to a garage designated or maintained by the city when any motor vehicle: 
(1)  Is parked in violation of any provision of this chapter which prohibits the parking of vehicles at the place where or at the time when the impounded motor vehicle is found. 
(2)  The continued presence of which, because of the physical location or condition of the motor vehicle, poses a danger to the public safety or to the motor vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. If any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(c)  Whenever, under the authority of this section, an officer removes a vehicle from a street and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner or for any other reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as provided in subsection (b) of this section and if the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three days, the officer shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal by mail to the secretary of state as provided in F.S. § 48.171, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle; the date, time and place from which removed; the reasons for such removal; and name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(Code 1960, § 28-106) 
Sec. 98-35. - Immobilization and removal of vehicles. 
(a)  Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police may immobilize a vehicle in such manner as to prevent the operation of such vehicle remaining in violation of this chapter in an onstreet or public parking lot space, the use of which is regulated by an official sign or which requires payment for any period longer than 48 hours. 
(b)  The registered owner of any vehicle for which five or more outstanding parking violation notices have been accumulated shall be notified by mail that such accumulation of outstanding parking violation notices shall subject the vehicle to immobilization under the provisions of this section. The notice shall inform the owner of the nature and number of outstanding violations, of the fact that such vehicle may be immobilized and impounded pursuant to this section and that the owner will be provided an opportunity to contest the validity of the proposed immobilization and impoundment upon written request to the chief of police within 15 days of mailing of the notice described in this subsection. 
(c)  Any owner who requests an opportunity to contest the validity of the proposed immobilization and impoundment of his vehicle in writing to the chief of police within 15 days of mailing of the notice described in subsection (b) of this section shall be provided an administrative hearing. Such hearing shall be scheduled as soon as practicable before the city manager or his designee, who shall be solely responsible for hearing and deciding all contests provided for in this subsection. Enforcement of the provisions of subsection (d) of this section shall be stayed pending the decision of the city manager or his designee. The purpose of this subsection is to provide an opportunity to contest the validity of a proposed immobilization and impoundment after 15 days from the date of mailing of the notice provided for in subsection (b) of this section and not to contest the merits of parking violations. 
(d)  At any time, officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police may immobilize those vehicles found parked upon any street or in any offstreet parking facility in the city when five or more outstanding or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices have accumulated against the vehicle for which there has been no payment, court order or adjudication or response by the vehicle owner pursuant to section 98-85. 
(e)  The police department having immobilized a vehicle under this section shall conspicuously affix a notice to such vehicle and shall mail, by the end of the next business day to the last known address of the registered owner of the vehicle, a notice, on a form provided by the city, for the driver or owner to pay the civil penalty specified and informing the owner of the vehicle that: 
(1)  Such vehicle (specifying the license number and briefly describing the parking violation notices issued to such vehicle) has been immobilized pursuant to and by the authority of this section; and 
(2)  The owner of such immobilized vehicle or otherwise duly authorized person shall be permitted to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle upon compliance with either of the following alternative procedures: 
a.  Payment to the director of finance or his designee of the total civil penalty, including delinquent fees, for each violation and an immobilization service charge of $75.00. 
b.  By signing and accepting a notice to appear establishing a date certain for a hearing on the immobilization of the vehicle. 
(f)  If, after contacting the appropriate state agency which acts as a custodian of vehicle registration and license tag records for the state from which the license tag attached to the motor vehicle was issued, the police department is unable to determine the motor vehicle owner's address, the motor vehicle may be immobilized in accordance with the provisions of this section, except that it shall not be necessary to mail the notice required in subsection (b) of this section. 
(g)  If the owner of such vehicle immobilized under the provisions of this section or other duly authorized person does not make arrangements for the removal of the immobilization device in accordance with this section and within 24 hours of the time such motor vehicle was immobilized, the police department may remove such vehicle to a garage or other place of safety in accordance with section 98-34. Any towing service charges incurred pursuant to this subsection shall be additional costs to be assessed to the registered owner of such motor vehicle. 
(h)  No vehicle immobilized in accordance with this section shall be immobilized by any means other than by the use of a device or other mechanism which will cause no damage to such vehicle, unless the vehicle is moved while such device or mechanism is in place. 
(i)  No person, except as may be authorized by the police department, shall remove or attempt to remove, tamper with or in any way damage or alter the immobilization device. A violation of this subsection shall result in the civil penalty set forth in section 98-81. 
(j)  Any vehicle immobilized pursuant to this section shall be subject to impoundment as authorized by section 98-34. 
(Code 1960, § 28-106.1) 
Secs. 98-36-98-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC DIVISION 

Sec. 98-46. - Established; duties. 
    There is established in the police department a traffic division under the control of an officer of the police department appointed by and directly responsible to the chief of police. It shall be the duty of the traffic division, with such aid as may be rendered by other members of the police department, to cooperate with the city traffic engineer and other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon the traffic division by this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 28-10) 
Sec. 98-47. - Investigation of accidents. 
    It shall be the duty of the traffic division, assisted by other police officers, to investigate traffic accidents and to arrest and assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Code 1960, § 28-11) 
Sec. 98-48. - Accident studies. 
    Whenever the traffic accidents at any particular location become numerous, the traffic division shall cooperate with the city traffic engineer in conducting studies of such accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(Code 1960, § 28-12) 
Sec. 98-49. - Accident reports. 
    The traffic division shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. Accident reports or cards referring to them shall be filed alphabetically by location. Such reports shall be available for the use and information of the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 1960, § 28-13) 
Sec. 98-50. - Annual traffic safety report. 
    The traffic division shall annually prepare a traffic report which shall be filed with the city manager. Such report shall contain information on traffic matters in this city as follows: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured, particular locations with numerous accidents and other pertinent traffic accident data. 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the police. 
(3)  The plans and recommendations of the division for future traffic safety activities. 
(Code 1960, § 28-14) 
Secs. 98-51-98-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices, F.S. § 316.008(1)(b); obedience to traffic control devices, F.S. § 316.074; uniformity of signals and devices, F.S. § 316.0745; traffic control signal device legend, F.S. §§ 316.075-316.0765. 

Sec. 98-61. - Authority to install. 
    The city manager shall place and maintain official traffic control devices when and as required under this chapter to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and may place and maintain such additional official traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate, warn or guide traffic under this chapter or state law. 
(Code 1960, § 28-30) 
Sec. 98-62. - Designation of crosswalks and establishment of safety zones. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Code 1960, § 28-31) 
Sec. 98-63. - Traffic lanes. 
    The city manager is authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(Code 1960, § 28-32) 
Sec. 98-64. - Applicability of state speed laws. 
    The state traffic laws regulating the speed of vehicles shall be applicable upon all streets within this city, except where the city manager declares and determines upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that certain speed regulations shall be applicable upon specified streets or in certain areas. In such event it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of any speed so declared when signs are in place giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 28-33) 
Sec. 98-65. - Devices altering normal course for turns. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to place official traffic control devices within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections. 
(Code 1960, § 28-34) 
Sec. 98-66. - Restricted turn signs. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right turn, left turn or U-turn and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the hours shall be plainly indicated on the signs or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(Code 1960, § 28-35) 
Sec. 98-67. - One-way streets and alleys. 
    Whenever the city manager designates any one-way street or alley, the city traffic engineer shall place and maintain signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulation shall be effective unless such signs are in place. Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1960, § 28-36) 
Sec. 98-68. - Restriction of direction of movement on streets during certain periods. 
    The city traffic engineer may erect signs temporarily designating lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction, regardless of the centerline of the roadway. 
(Code 1960, § 28-37) 
Sec. 98-69. - Signs required at through streets. 
    Whenever the city manager designates a through street, it shall be the duty of the city traffic engineer to place and maintain a stop sign or, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation at any intersection, a yield sign on each and every street intersecting such through street, unless traffic at any such intersection is controlled at all times by traffic control signals. However, at the intersection of two such through streets or at the intersection of a through street and a heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall be erected at the approaches of either of such streets as may be determined by the city traffic engineer upon the basis of an engineering and traffic study. 
(Code 1960, § 28-38) 
Sec. 98-70. - Other intersections where stop or yield required. 
    The city traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate intersections where a particular hazard exists upon other than through streets and to determine whether vehicles shall: 
(1)  Stop at one or more entrances to any such intersection, at which intersection he shall cause to be erected a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required; or 
(2)  Yield the right-of-way to vehicles on a different street at such intersection, at which intersection he shall cause to be erected a yield sign at every place where obedience thereto is required. 
(Code 1960, § 28-39) 
Sec. 98-71. - Designation of special residential parking districts; permits required; exemptions. 
(a)  Special residential parking districts. Areas within the city may be designated as special residential parking districts in the manner described in this section, and after being so designated shall be subject to the regulations set forth in this section, together with any other regulations or laws not inconsistent herewith. 
(b)  Declaration of special residential parking districts by city manager. The city manager may approve and declare an area to be designated as a special residential parking district upon the receipt of a petition representing 66 percent of homeowners within the area, providing such area is deemed appropriate for residential parking designation by the city manager after consultation with city staff. After review by city staff and the city manager, notice of designation of special residential parking district shall be sent to all persons identified on the petition and insofar as practical to all other residents or property owners in the district. 
(c)  Declaration of special residential parking districts by city commission. The city commission may, by resolution, approve and declare an area to be designated as a special residential parking district if the city commission determines such area would appropriately receive such designation. The city commission may, if it deems it to be proper or necessary, impose parking restrictions to accompany its declaration of a special residential parking district. The city commission may request a review by the city manager and/or city staff prior to approving a resolution declaring a special residential parking district. Prior to the city commission's approval of such a district, notice of a designation of special residential parking district shall be sent to all persons identified as property owners in the district, insofar as possible. 
(d)  Application for permit exempting automobile from special residential parking district parking restrictions. 
(1)  Any resident residing within a special residential parking district and who wishes to apply for a parking permit to allow on-street parking in that district shall file an application with the Winter Park Finance Department. As of the effective date of this ordinance, no more than two permits shall be issued per single-family housing unit in said special residential parking district. 
(2)  In areas designated as special residential parking districts with signs displaying the message "EXCEPT BY RESIDENTIAL PERMIT," passenger motor vehicles displaying authorized municipal residential parking permits as discussed in this section are allowed to park on residential streets within the district covered by their permits, and are hereby exempt from city regulations requiring "no parking," parking prohibited during specified hours and parking time limits on specified streets within said district. Said permits will exempt vehicles as herein defined from the provisions herein enumerated only within the special residential parking district in which the owner of the vehicle resides. No other exemptions are permitted. 
(e)  Contents of permit application. The application for a residential parking permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Residential address; 
(3)  The make, model and license registration number; 
(4)  The principal driver's license number. 
    The motor vehicle registration, operator's license, and proof of residence must be presented at the time of application. 
(f)  Display of permit. 
(1)  The residential parking permit shall be displayed on the outside bottom left-hand corner of the rear window so that the driver's view will not be obscured in any manner. The design and content of the permit shall be approved by the city manager and or designee. 
(2)  In the event that the motor vehicle on which the permit is displayed is sold, transferred, or demolished and the permit is not removed from the motor vehicle, the person to whom the permit was issued may request and shall be issued a duplicate permit. It shall be the duty of that person to notify the city that the motor vehicle on which the permit was displayed is no longer owned by him and to make additional application in accordance with the provisions of this section for the duplicate permit. The duplicate permit shall be issued and valid for the unexpired term of the original permit without additional charge. The original permit, upon the issuance of the duplicate permit, shall be invalid. 
(g)  Renewal of permit. Residential parking permits shall be valid for one year, and shall be renewed each year. The permit year shall begin July 1st and end June 30th. Permits for the upcoming permit year may be purchased beginning in June of the current year. 
    Residential parking permits shall be considered in force and valid for a period of 30 days following the listed permit year. 
(h)  Special permission to park. 
(1)  In special residential parking districts, any nonresidential land user that does not have off-street parking may apply to the city for such parking permits to allow limited parking on the street. 
(2)  The regulation and administration of the parking permits as described in subsection (h)(1) will be the responsibility of the public works department. The public works department shall establish administrative rules to regulate this subsection. 
(i)  Misuse and alteration of residential parking permits. No person shall: 
(1)  Display, cause or permit to be displayed, or be in possession of any residential parking permit, knowing the same to be fictitious, or to be revoked, canceled, suspended, or altered. 
(2)  Lend such residential parking permit to, or knowingly permit the use of same, by one not entitled to the use of such permit. 
(3)  Whoever violates any provision of this section shall have his or her parking permit privileges revoked for one year from the date of the violation. 
(j)  Designated special residential parking districts on file. A current listing of all designated special residential parking districts shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. Notice of newly designated residential parking districts shall be distributed to mayor and city commission, the city manager's office, the police department, and the public works department. 
(Ord. No. 2745-08, § 1, 8-25-08) 
Secs. 98-72-98-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 98-81. - Schedule of civil penalties for parking and other violations. 
    The schedule of civil penalties for parking and other violations occurring within the city for which payment may be made to the finance department shall be as prescribed by the city commission from time to time and set forth in its "Schedule of City of Winter Park Service and User Fees and Charges. 
(Code 1960, § 28-100; Ord. No. 2011, § 1, 7-27-93; Ord. No. 2571-04, § 2, 3-22-04; Ord. No. 2622-05, § 2, 3-28-05) 
State Law reference- Parking violations, F.S. § 316.1967. 
Sec. 98-82. - Forms and records of parking violation notices. 
    The chief of police shall be responsible for providing books of parking violation notices to be issued by individual members of the police department. The chief of police shall require a written receipt for every book so issued and shall maintain a record of every such book and each set of citations contained therein. The books shall include serially numbered sets of notices, in duplicate, in the form prescribed and approved jointly by the city manager and the chief of police. 
(Code 1960, § 28-101) 
Sec. 98-83. - Audit of records and reports. 
    Every record of a parking violation notice and a warrant issued therefor required in this division shall be subject to audit annually by the finance director, who shall submit a report of such audit, together with a summary thereof, to the city manager. 
(Code 1960, § 28-102) 
Sec. 98-84. - Notice on illegally parked vehicle-Generally. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without its driver is found parked, standing or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its tag number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user. The officer shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a parking violation notice, on a form provided by the city, for the driver to pay the civil penalty specified or answer to the charge against him within five days during the hours and at a place specified in the notice. 
(Code 1960, § 28-103) 
Sec. 98-85. - Same-Failure to comply. 
(a)  If a violator of the traffic laws or ordinances does not pay the civil penalty specified or respond to a parking violation notice affixed to a motor vehicle within a period of five days, a delinquent fee shall be assessed in accordance with the current adopted fee schedule of the city against the registered owner for failure to obey the notice. If there is no payment or response for a period exceeding 30 days, a notice of summons shall be sent by certified mail to the registered owner of the motor vehicle for which the parking violation notice was issued, informing such owner of the parking violation notice and of the failure to comply therewith. Such notice shall direct the recipient to respond within 15 calendar days; otherwise, a summons may be issued for failure to comply in violation of this section. Costs per violation shall be assessed in accordance with the current adopted fee schedule of the city for the administration of this notification process. 
(b)  If a response is not made within the 15 days specified in the notice of summons, a summons may be issued commanding an appearance before a judge of the county court and a service of process charge per summons shall be assessed in accordance with the current adopted fee schedule of the city. 
(c)  After issuance of summons, a hearing on the charge of failure to comply shall be scheduled and such charge prosecuted in the county court. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be deemed a separate and distinct violation and shall not be construed to be merged with or part of the original parking violation. 
(e)  Any person who fails to respond to the original parking violation notice within the time specified on such notice shall be deemed to have waived the right to pay a civil penalty. 
(Code 1960, § 28-104; Ord. No. 2171, § 1, 10-22-96) 
State Law reference- Parking violations, F.S. § 316.1967. 
Sec. 98-86. - Same-Alteration or destruction. 
(a)  No person, whether the recipient thereof or otherwise, shall willfully throw away, alter, mar, mutilate, destroy or discard the written notice of the city described in section 98-85(a). No persons finding affixed on any vehicle the written notice of the city described in section 98-85(a), whether he is the owner, operator or driver of or passenger in the vehicle to which the notice is affixed, shall willfully throw away, alter, mar, mutilate, destroy or discard the written notice of the city so found affixed to such vehicle. No person, whether or not the owner or operator of a vehicle to which may be found affixed the written notice of the city described in section 98-85(a), shall willfully remove, take away, throw away, mar, alter, mutilate, destroy or discard any such written notice so affixed. No person shall receive any such notice from another for the purpose of so mutilating or destroying the notice or for the purpose of constituting himself the agent of the recipient for any purpose other than the proper and lawful adjustment with the finance department of the charge contained in such notice. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place in the envelope provided with and accompanying the parking violation notice any item or object other than the written notice, currency or a check in payment therefor. 
(Code 1960, § 28-104.1) 
Sec. 98-87. - Same-Additional penalties. 
    Any person violating any provision of sections 98-85 and 98-86, except where a penalty is specifically prescribed for the particular violation, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1960, § 28-104.2) 
Sec. 98-88. - Disposition of parking fines and forfeitures. 
    All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into the city treasury and deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 28-105) 
Sec. 98-89. - Interference with overtime parking enforcement. 
    No person shall erase, obscure or alter in any manner whatsoever the chalk mark placed upon the tire of a parked vehicle by any traffic enforcement officer so as to interfere with the enforcement of the overtime parking regulations. No person shall move a motor vehicle within a parking space to erase, obscure or alter the chalk mark placed on the vehicle by a traffic enforcement officer so as to interfere with the enforcement of the overtime parking regulations. 
(Code 1960, § 28-107) 
Sec. 98-90. - Nonpayment of outstanding parking violation notices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner of any vehicle to accumulate three or more outstanding parking violations. A parking violation notice shall be deemed outstanding if there has been no payment or response within the time periods specified in section 98-85. 
(b)  The traffic division is hereby authorized and directed to supply the State of Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles with a listing of persons, in a State Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles approved communications format, who have three or more outstanding parking violations or one or more outstanding parking violations of F.S. § 316.1955 or any city ordinance which regulates parking in spaces designated for use by persons who have disabilities. 
(Code 1960, § 28-108; Ord. No. 2570-04, § 1, 3-22-04) 
Sec. 98-91. - Surcharge on parking fines. 
(a)  A surcharge in the amount of $5.00 is imposed on all parking fines for parking violations occurring within the city, for the sole purpose of funding school crossing guard programs. 
(b)  This surcharge shall be placed in the school crossing guard trust fund and funds collected from this surcharge shall be distributed quarterly to fund school crossing guard programs. However, the city may set aside funds from this surcharge to pay for start up costs and recurring administrative costs related to printing new tickets or other means of implementing the school crossing guard program. 
(Ord. No. 2164, § 1, 10-8-96) 
Secs. 98-92-98-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVING RULES 

Sec. 98-111. - Limitations on vehicles using streets. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate on streets within the city any vehicle or combination of vehicles whose weight, when added to the weight of its load, is more than 15,000 pounds and whose height from ground level to the highest point (exclusive of antennae) on either the vehicle or the combination of vehicles or the load on either is more than thirteen feet and six inches. However, it shall not be unlawful for any person to operate such vehicle or combination of vehicles as is prohibited in this section if the operator of the otherwise prohibited vehicle is going directly to or from a place in the city where the vehicle or combination of vehicles was or will be loaded or unloaded, or will otherwise service a property within the City, and that place within the City cannot be reached from either inside or outside the City via streets without weight and height limitations; provided, that this exception to weight and height limitations shall not apply to any street for which the signs are erected completely prohibiting any vehicle or combination of vehicles exceeding said weight and height limitations. It shall also not be unlawful for any person to operate such vehicle or combination of vehicles as is prohibited in this section after permission is granted from the City by issuance of a special permit. 
    An overweight and/or oversize vehicle and/or commercial motor vehicle is any self-propelled or towed vehicle used in commerce or cargo if such vehicle has a gross vehicle weight rating of 15,000 pounds, or any vehicle over 15,000 pounds. 
(Code 1960, § 28-90; Ord. No. 2372, § 1, 9-12-00) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict use of streets, F.S. § 316.008(1)(g). 
Sec. 98-112. - Drivers in a procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the righthand edge of the roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1960, § 28-50) 
State Law reference- Funeral or other processions, F.S. § 316.1974; authority to regulate processions, F.S. § 316.008(1)(c). 
Secs. 98-113-98-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking generally, F.S. § 316.1945 et seq.; authority to regulate stopping, standing and parking, F.S. § 316.008(1)(a). 

Sec. 98-136. - Parking signs required. 
    Whenever by this chapter or any other ordinance of this city any parking time limit is imposed on designated streets, the city traffic engineer shall erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof. No such regulations shall be effective unless the signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1960, § 28-84) 
Sec. 98-137. - Owner responsible for illegal parking. 
    Subject to F.S. § 316.1967, no person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park on any street in the city in violation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1960, § 28-85) 
Sec. 98-138. - Signs or markings indicating angle parking. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer shall determine where angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal-aid or state highway within this city unless the state department of transportation has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. 
(b)  Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street. 
(Code 1960, § 28-60) 
Sec. 98-139. - Obedience to angle parking signs or markings. 
    On those streets or parking lots which have been signed or marked by the city traffic engineer for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings, with the front wheel against the curb and with the vehicle not protruding across the markings. 
(Code 1960, § 28-61) 
Sec. 98-140. - Permits for loading or unloading at angle to curb. 
(a)  The traffic division may issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials, subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permit may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1960, § 28-62) 
Sec. 98-141. - Parallel parking spaces. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer shall designate parking spaces parallel to the curb by appropriate markings upon the curb or the pavement. Parking spaces so designated shall be of appropriate length and width as to be accessible from the traffic lanes. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle in any such designated parking space so that any part of such vehicle occupies more than one such space or protrudes beyond the markings designating such space, except that a vehicle of a size too large to be parked within a single designated parking zone shall be permitted to occupy two adjoining parking spaces. 
(Code 1960, § 28-63) 
Sec. 98-142. - Parking at Fleet Peeples Park. 
    When any vehicle shall be parked in Fleet Peeples Park, the operator of such vehicle shall, upon entering the park, immediately purchase a parking ticket by depositing the required coins of the United States in the parking ticket dispenser located at the park entrance. The parking ticket shall be displayed on the dash of the vehicle so long as the vehicle remains in the park and shall be valid only for the date stamped on the ticket. However, a vehicle operator possessing a valid use fee card issued by the recreation department may display the use fee card in lieu of a parking ticket. 
(Code 1960, § 28-64; Ord. No. 2835-11, § 5, 1-24-11; Ord. No. 2838-11, § 2.e., 4-11-11) 
Sec. 98-143. - Parking on city-owned or city-leased property. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer may make recommendations to the city commission regarding the adoption and promulgation of rules to regulate traffic and parking and the towing or removal of vehicles illegally parked on city-owned or city-leased property. Any recommendations made by the city engineer pursuant to this section may be reviewed, adopted, modified or rejected by the city commission. The city traffic engineer shall erect, place and maintain signs, devices and markings giving notice where parking is regulated or prohibited by action of the city commission and designating tow-away areas by appropriate tow-away signs. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle on city-owned or city-leased property: 
(1)  At any place where official signs or traffic control devices prohibit stopping, standing or parking. 
(2)  In any parking space designated for members of the city commission or city boards, unless such person is a member of the city commission or city board. 
(3)  In any parking space designated for city employees unless such vehicle has affixed to the rear of such vehicle an appropriate city employee decal issued by the city traffic engineer. 
(4)  In any parking space designated for any other person. 
(5)  In any parking space beyond the time stated on any official sign limiting the parking time for such parking space. 
(6)  In any manner contrary to any ordinance, rule or regulation of the city commission, when a sign has been erected giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 28-64.1) 
Sec. 98-144. - Use of proceeds from parking devices. 
(a)  The coins required to be deposited in parking gates or ticket dispensers as provided in this article are levied and assessed as fees to cover the following: 
(1)  The regulation and control of parking upon public streets; 
(2)  The costs of: 
a.  Parking control devices, their installation, inspection, supervision, operation, repair and maintenance; 
b.  Control and use of parking spaces; and 
c.  Regulating the parking of vehicles in parking lots; and 
(3)  The costs of acquiring, establishing, improving, maintaining and operating public offstreet parking facilities. 
(b)  The coins deposited in parking gates or ticket dispensers shall be collected by the duly authorized agents of the city and shall be deposited in a special account to be known as the parking facilities account. 
(c)  The city shall pay from such special fund the costs of any parking control devices purchased by the city and installed as provided in this chapter and expenses incurred for maintenance. The net proceeds of the operation of parking control devices in the special fund, after the payment of such costs and expenses, shall be used for parking studies and for the acquisition, establishment, improvement, maintenance and operation of public offstreet parking facilities as the city commission shall from time to time direct. 
(Code 1960, § 28-65) 
Sec. 98-145. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon a street or alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic; provided, however, that where traffic will not be interfered with, operators of cars or other vehicles may stop momentarily for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Code 1960, § 28-66) 
Sec. 98-146. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any public or private roadway, public parking lot or any other public property for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale, rental or hire; 
(2)  Washing, polishing, painting, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
(3)  Displaying commercial advertising, but this provision shall not apply to vehicles which are regularly (at least five times per week) used for delivery services, and are otherwise legally parked, where the vehicle merely displays identifying information, logos, and similar marks of the business for which deliveries are made; neither shall this provision apply to work trucks, vans, or other vehicles actually used in the operations of a business which merely display identifying information, logos, and similar marks of the business in which the vehicle is used; or 
(4)  Selling merchandise from the vehicle, except in an established marketplace or when authorized or permitted by the city. 
Violation of this section shall be considered a civil infraction, and a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 28-67; Ord. No. 2703-07, § 1, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 98-147. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer may erect signs indicating no parking upon either or both sides of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon either side of a street adjacent to any school property as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 28-68) 
Sec. 98-148. - Parking prohibited on narrow streets. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer may erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed 20 feet or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed 30 feet. 
(b)  When official signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1960, § 28-69) 
Sec. 98-149. - Standing or parking on one-way streets. 
    The city traffic engineer may erect signs upon the lefthand side of any one-way street to prohibit the standing or parking of vehicles. When such signs are in place, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon such lefthand side in violation of any such sign. 
(Code 1960, § 28-70) 
Sec. 98-150. - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. 
    If a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the lefthand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The city traffic engineer may determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the lefthand side of any such one-way roadway and erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 28-71) 
Sec. 98-151. - Stopping, standing or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer may determine and designate by proper signs or markings places in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. Likewise, the city traffic engineer shall designate by proper signs or markings fire lanes, as determined by the city fire marshal, in carrying out provisions of the city's fire prevention code. 
(b)  When official signs are erected or the curb marked by painting it red or yellow at hazardous or congested places as authorized in this section, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 28-72) 
Sec. 98-152. - Parking on parkways. 
(a)  Except where official signs are erected permitting parking on parkways, no person shall stop or park a vehicle upon any such parkway. This subsection is not applicable to a person driving or in charge of a licensed utility truck or other utility vehicle while engaged in official utilities functions. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer may determine and designate by proper signs such parkways where parking would not create a vision obstruction or other traffic hazard and would not cause environmental damage by compacting the soil, thereby decreasing percolation and increasing stormwater runoff. 
(Code 1960, § 28-73) 
Sec. 98-153. - Parking of commercial vehicles on Park Avenue. 
    Parking of commercial, freight or delivery vehicles is prohibited on Park Avenue, except where there is no alley or side street where parking would be available near the location being served by such vehicles. 
(Code 1960, § 28-74) 
Sec. 98-154. - Designation of curb loading zones. 
    The city traffic engineer may determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the loading zones and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(Code 1960, § 28-75) 
Sec. 98-155. - Standing in passenger curb loading zone. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, in any placed marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed five minutes. 
(Code 1960, § 28-76)
